column2: Gradual clearing up of bottlenecks is resulting in the best comparative flow of a variety of home appliance items since V-J Day, but over all hangs the threat of what the continued coal and copper strikes will do to production in the very near future. As of yesterday,

The stock market threw off yesterday its recent sluggishness and bolstered by bids heavily weighted on the higher side rallied to new highs for the year in the industrial issues. Wide upward swings were
TRENTON, N.J. April 16 (AP)-- A New Caledonia war bride brought her 6-month-old son 10,000 miles to join her veteran husband,

WASHINGTON, April 16--Senate debate on the Anglo-American trade and financial agreement, under which the United States would give a $3,750,000,000 credit to Great Britain in return for relaxation of trade controls, will open tomorrow with Administration leaders predicting approval by a substantial margin.
A group of eighty-eight banking firms headed by Halsey, Stuart Co. yesterday won the award of $41,500,000 of refunding mortgage bonds of 1986 of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate)

If in Maine there at a only two seasons, winter and August, it is equally true that for many thousands of Americans the year's only season that really counts began yesterday when southpaw Truman tossed out the first ball.

The background of the British-American insistence that the Security Council retain jurisdiction over the Iran case until the Red Army troops go home is contained in one or two important considerations that most members of the Council believe to be significant.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16--The Poor Richard Club presented a citation to John S. Knight today in recognition of his achievements as president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors during the war years and "his outstanding services to his country" as liaison

PHILADELPHIA, April 16--In a complaint filed with Federal Judge Paul C. Leahy at Wilmington, Del., the Securities and Exchange Commission this afternoon accused the management of TransAmerica Corporation of having "willfully violated the proxy rules."
United Nations officials and American scientists expressed concern yesterday over the delay of the international Atomic Energy Commission in opening discussions on the control of nuclear fission.

ROME, April 16--A German officer who was infiltrated into Arnerican lines in August, 1944, as a spy has posed successfully for more than a year as an American captain and was detected only after conniving at the theft of a jeep from the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, it was revealed here today.

BOSTON, April 16--Drastic changes in passenger-car design to assure greater vision were urged today by Governor Baldwin of Connecticut and Governor Dale of New Hampshire at the Massachusetts Safety Conference.
WASHINGTON, April 16--The CIO Political Action Committee carved out its 1946 program today and called upon all voters "to measure the record of every candidate for office against this program."

A syndicate of 149 investment bankers headed by Morgan Stanley Co. here will place today on the investment market $125,000,000 of twenty-five-year 2 per cent debentures of the Shell Union Oil Corporation. This will be the larg

The intrusion of modern design into the essentially traditional domain of fine china is marked by the opening today at the Museum of Modern Art of an exhibit of dinnerware designed by Eva Zeisel and produced by Castleton China.
ARCADIA, Calif., Aprit 16 (AP)-- East and West shared honors today as the Santa Anita Grand Circuit harness race meeting opened.

NEWARK, N.J., April 16-- School officials here do not believe that "sparing the rod spoils the child," according to Dr. Bruce B. Robinson, director of child guidance for Newark schools, who took issue today with a suggestion by a woman teacher-lawyer that laws forbidding corporal punishment in New Jersey be repealed.

NEW DELHI, India, April 16-- The British Cabinet mission held the first of two highly important discussions today, meeting Mohammed Ali Jinnah, leader of the Moslem League, for an hour and forty minutes.

WASHINGTON, April 16--A report stating that "substantial progress" had been made in the last three months in returning lowcost apparel to retail stores was issued today by John D. Small, Civilian Production Administrator, in sharp contrast to appraisals of the clothing program made last week by the head of his Textile Division and by Chester Bowles, Director of Economic Stabilization.

WASHINGTON, April 16--President Truman signed without comment today the "anti-Petrillo" bill establishing criminal penalties for compelling or attempting to coerce radio broadcasters to submit to "featherbed" employment practices.

ATHENS, Greece, April 16--A request that the Minister of the Interior made to the Allies, that each retain one observer who had served in the elections to help the Greek Government in the task of recompiling electoral lists, is to be studied in Washington, London and ...
Throughout the whole debate over Iran nothing has been more revealing or significant for the future than the position taken by the smaller nations represented on the Council.

In the eight-day period ended at midnight Monday there were 191 cases of major crime, including murder, manslaughter, homicide, felonious assault, assault and robbery, burglary, rape and possession of dangerous weapons, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander disclosed yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP)--The highly-touted St. Louis Cardinals' mound staff developed the jitters in today's opening National League game here and the Redbirds, after an explosive three-run first inning, were tramped on by the slugging Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-4, before 14,009 paid spectators.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 16 (AP)-- Premier Ahmad Ghavam, in a communique read tonight over the Teheran radio, announced his determination to put down disorders with force and called on Iranian law enforcement officers to carry out his instructions with the "utmost resolve."
Putting on a gorgeous variety show that included first-inning home runs by Manager Melvin Ott and monumental Ernie Lombardi,

LONDON, April 16--A sharp warning that the slogan, "One State, one commissar" might replace the Nazis' "one State one Fuehrer" in Germany, was delivered in the House of Lords today by Lord Jowitt, the Lord Chancellor.

MEXICO CITY, April 16--The principle of free enterprise as against Government control and industrial socialization was upheld at the long and heated discussions by the third labor conference of the American States, members of the International Labor Organization, which ended its work here today.

LONDON, April 16 (AP)--Four American soldier prisoners took the witness stand today in the Lichfield detention camp trial after having been assured by Brig. Gen. Edward C. Betts, United States judge advocate in the European theatre, that they would not be "persecuted" for giving evidence.

TOKYO, April 16--Baron Kijuro Shidehara today told the Japanese press and public that he intended to remain in office as Premier at least until the draft of the new Constitution is ratified by the Parliament and the political situation brought on by the general election is "stabilized."

To interest the young in reading, adults need to know as much about children as they do about books, according to the latest symposium on the subject released yesterday by the Association for Childhood Education.

CHICAGO, April 16--May rye reached the highest price on record today on the Board of Trade, selling at $2.48 a bushel at one time, as a result of buying by commission houses with Eastern connections, but reacted 7/8 cent from the top and finished 2 7/8 cents higher for the day. Minneapolis May rye

CINCINNATI, April 16 (AP)-- The Chicago Cubs, 1945 National League champions, opened their season today with a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds, their "cousins" of a year ago, but they almost didn't make it.

Youthful ice and roller skating enthusiasts who enjoy their pastime in the New York City Building on the old World's Fair site received assurances yesterday from Mayor O'Dwyer that international affairs would not cast permanent clouds over their peaceful pursuits.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., April 16-- Lionel Hogarth, retired veteran actor who had appeared on Broadway with Maurice Evans, Maude Adams and other stars, died at the Brunswick Home here yesterday, the day before his seventy-second birthday, after a long illness. In private life he was Lionel Hogarth Swann.

Propped up in his hospital bed at Harkness Pavilion, Dr. Chang Po-ling, president of Nankai University in Tientsin, China, smiled serenely yesterday as he discussed the subject to which he has devoted fifty of his seventy years-- education in his country.

The bodies of three boys, two of whom were 7 years old and the other 6, were found last night in the ruins of an unused chicken coop behind the house at 9-19 127th Street, College Point, Queens, after a mysterious fire had wrecked the wooden structure.

NEWARK, N.J., April 16--A luncheon table combining copper accessories and verdigris-glazed mugs and plates received first prize today in a table arrangement competition jointly sponsored by Bamberger's and seven New Jersey branches of the American Association of University Women.

LONDON, April 16--A sharp curtailment of exports from Britain of food products containing grain or sugar was announced in the House of Commons today by Sir Ben Smith, Minister of Food, in a move designed to conserve supplies of scarce items for the home market.

GENEVA, April 16 (AP)--The League of Nations, convened in its twenty-first and last session, made a gesture of friendship toward the Soviet Union today, but a motion to give Russia a share of the League assets was rejected.

The Navy couldn't make Miss Ina S. Lindman of this city an Admiral, for she was a civilian. It did the best it could and awarded her, the other day, the Distinguished Civilian Service citation, Miss Lindman did not take part in any battle. She did not invent radar.
The following is a summary of Foreign Minister Juan Isaac Cooke's reply to the State Department's Blue Book on Argentina:

LONDON, April 17-The Dominions' Ministers, who will start arriving here next week to discuss British Empire problems, will be asked to approve the British plan for the Ruhr before it is placed before the conference of Big Four Foreign Ministers in Paris.

The mentally ill among our service men, constituting 30 to 40 per cent of our war casualties, are not receiving the treatment that holds out the greatest promise for their recovery because of the lack of physicians properly trained in the administration of insulin therapy, ...
WASHINGTON, April 17--The Argentine Government considers that it would be "absurd" to prolong the controversy with the United States caused by the State Department's publication of its
CHICAGO, April 17--Pledged to support the interests of the holders of the common and preferred stock, an independent proxy committee with headauarters here ...

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is negotiating an $80,000,000 bank loan to meet its financial obligations and enable it to go ahead with a $58,000,000 expansion and improvement program in 1946, despite the ninety-three-dayold strike of Congress of Industrial Organizations workers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 17 --Cary Grant and Shirley Temple have been named by RKO for the co-starring leads in "Bachelor and Bobby-Sox," a screen story by Sidney Sheldon, which the Company has acquired under a profit-sharing deal from David O. Selznick.

WASHINGTON, April 17--The Republican party was depicted as "the one truly liberal political party in the United States" today by Representative Reece of Tennessee, its new national chairman, in a speech to the National Press Club.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, April 17--"A mad market with blind buying" was the description by some brokers today of conditions prevailing on the Johannes-I burg Stock Exchange. The "gold fever" has developed following reports of unprecedented results from a borehole in the Orange Free State.

PITTSBURGH, April 17--The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, will resume negotiations here tomorrow morning toward ending the ninety-three-day strike by 75,000 production workers seeking an 18 -cent hourly wage increase, the corporation announced today.
DETROIT, April 17 (U.P.)--Crippling steel shortages caused by the coal strike today forced the Ford Motor Company to lay off half its 90,000 production workers in its third shutdown in three months.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hutchinson of 510 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Gilbert, to Comdr. Merrill Kinsell Clementson, USN, son of Mrs. Clyde Kelly of Washington, D. C., and the late Dr. William A. Clementson of Pittsburgh.

Retail-trade groups are carefully watching compliance of so-called "Army-Navy stores" with the State law signed early this month by Governor Dewey which regulates use of the words "Army, Navy"' and similar terms in the trade name or description of the seller or place of business, it was reported here yesterday.

BOSTON, April 17(U.P.)--A move to unionize professional baseball players was revealed tonight when the American Baseball Guild registered as a labor organization in Suffolk County and announced it already had "substantial membership" in ten major league clubs.

An exhibition of original illustrations for children's books opened yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art in the Young People's Gallery. It includes drawings and paintings by illustrators and wellknown artists, as well as books, ...

The Security Council of the United Nations shifted its attention from the still unresolved Iranian issue to the equally perplexing Spanish question yesterday and the change in agenda was reflected clearly on the floor.
WASHINGTON, April 17--Edwin Stanton, a career diplomat who now is consul general at Vancouver, B. C., was appointed by President Truman today to be Minister to Siam.

Magistrate J. Roland Sala's rejection of a parking summons fixed to his automobile last Monday as it stood in a no-parking area outside Mid-Manhattan Court in East Fifty-seventh Street, awakened reverberations yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, April 17--The Argentine Government, acting by decree, today assumed control of all wheat exports and took steps to get wheat from the farms, where it has been hoarded in the hope of higher world prices, to shipping points.

ALBANY, April 17--George R. Loveys, executive assistant to Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein and former State editor of The Associated Press, died today at the Albany Hospital. He was stricken with a cerebral hemorrhage at his Delmar home last night, a few hours after leaving his office in the Capitol.

"Woman Bites Dog" is about the fourth estate, which is the estate of angels, although some of them have fallen here and there. Bella and Samuel Spewack have taken up three of the latter, two with military or naval titles and the other a female relative, all newspaper owners.

Vincent Youmans, composer of popular songs, who died of tuberculosis from which he had suffered twelve years, left virtually all his estate to create the Vincent Youmans Tuberculosis Memorial as a public charity, it was disclosed yesterday.

PARIS, April 17-Despite the split in the coalition, the Assembly today went on building the Constitution on the Socialist-Communist theory of Assembly rule, leaving the question of the Cabinet's future up to President Felix Gouin.

SALEM, Mass., April 17--First Lieut. Marie A. Eastman died yesterday, at Salem Hospital, after knowing for two years that she was soon to die. A 33-year-old Army nurse who had served overseas since 1943, Lieutenant Eastman had suffered of a stomach cancer while on duty abroad.

WASHINGTON, April 17--Efforts are being made by both distillers and liquor importers to persuade the Treasury Department's alcoholic tax unit to amend regulations so as to require at least 10 per cent of sugar in any liqueur whisky and to set minimum age requirements for "Scotch type" whiskies.

WASHINGTON, April 17--House Administration leaders, aided by superior numbers of Northern Democrats, succeeded tonight in preventing the Southern Democratic revolt from spreading to further public attacks on the national committee and Robert E. Hannegan, its chairman, but failed to effect a harmony which will put an end to coalitions or change many, if any, votes.

DETROIT, April 17 (AP)--Scoring twice in the eighth on Walt Judnich's home run and twice more in the ninth against a parade of three pitchers, the Browns came from behind today to beat the Tigers, 7 to 6.

OTTAWA, April 17 (AP)--The Prices Board announced tonight suspension of the basic price ceiling of $54 a ton on newsprint sold in Canada, subject to a "clear understanding" that Canadian prices will not rise beyond "historic differentials."
Rustem Vembery, noted liberal, who recently was elected to the Hungarian National Assembly, has completed the manuscript of his new book "Hungary: To Be or Not to Be."

ALBANY, April 17--A bill which will save New York City condemnation awards of possibly $5,500,000 in connection with the construction of the Delaware water project was approved today by Governor Dewey. Another bill which would have reduced Staten Island ferry charges was vetoed.

TOKYO, April 17--At today's session of the Allied Council for Japan Brig. Gen. Courtney Whitney answered in detail "charges" by the Russians that undesirable persons remained in public life despite the Jan. 4 purge directive.

LONDON, April 17--The British Government's present plans for the future of the iron and steel industry, the main point in which is a "large measure of public ownership," were announced in the House of Commons today by John

WASHINGTON, April 17--The importance to the world of knowing what is taking place in Iran, and especially during the next few weeks when Russian troops are pledged to withdraw from the country, was placed in high relief today through two sudden and contrasting announcements:
The new screen-printed wallpapers that have appeared on the decorating scene during the last few months seem to have outstripped printed fabrics on the score of freshness and originality.
WASHINGTON, April 17--Mrs. Mary Ashby Lerch, formerly of New York, died here on Sunday, at her home after a brief illness. She was in her ninety-sixth year.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has sold the fourteenstory and penthouse apartment building at the southwest corner of Broadway and Ninety-eighth Street to Albert H. Graham, operator, in ...

ALBANY, April 17--The State Education Department notified the New York City Board of Education today that the United Parents Association and others had appealed from its decision dismissing charges against May Quinn, a teacher. It also notified Miss Quinn that charges had been filed with it looking to revocation of her teaching license.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)-- Paul Porter, OPA administrator, took notice of the House's "profit-on-every-product" action in testimony before the Senate Banking Committee.

State leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations are giving sympathetic consideration to a proposal by Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi for the establishment of machinery to prevent inter-union fights from halting production or retarding reconversion, it was learned last night.

WASHINGTON, April 17--The State Department received today through the embassy in Madrid the invitation of the Spanish Government for the United States and four other "friendly" members of the United Nations to send commissions to Spain to investigate charges that Germans were working on atomic secrets there.
A chronology of the major developments in the establishment of the Franco regime in Spain follows:

WASHINGTON, April 17--John D. Small, Civilian Production Administrator, reported today that "the nation's reconversion program is suffering a setback which will steadily grow worse day by day if the coal strike continues." The report, on

CHICAGO, April 17--One reason for the meat shortage is that the country is trying to support, on limited feed supplies, one of the largest flocks of chickens and turkeys in history, livestock producers asserted today.

WITH the start of the new baseball season a great number of stalwart young men will have made their major league debuts, some successfully and some unsuccessfully but none of any real significance until they can be weighed in the halls of time.
WASHINGTON, April 17--The Senate Majority Leader, Alben W. Barkley, opening debate today on the proposed $3,750,000,000 credit to Great Britain, replied to the
TREASURY STATEMENT

WASHINGTON, April 17--While President Truman maintained silence today about the House's draft extension bill and expressed a hope that the Senate would pass a workable measure, it was learned that high military leaders felt the gravest concern over the possible international consequences unless there was a clear-cut extension of Selective Service.
The Dry Dock Savings Institution sold the six-story apartment house at 120 East Second Street to the 204 Henry Street Corporation, Arthur Unger, president, through the Sanford Chobol Company, broker.

VIENNA, April 17--The Austrian Minister of Education has put an abrupt end to the agitation of schools against the return of crucifixes to schoolrooms. The Nazis had removed the crucifixes that customarily were found in Austrian schools.

WASHINGTON, April 17-- Henry J. Kaiser was denounced today on the Senate floor by Senator Bridges of New Hampshire as "a coddled darling of the New Deal" who now owed the Reconstruction Finance Corporation almost $115,000,000.

Net profit of Bonwit Teller, Inc., for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, amounted to $1,100,093, equal, after preferred dividends, to $8.98 a share for the common stock, comparing with $619,477, or $4.65 a share, earned in the preceding year, according to William M. Holmes, president.

Three more days of this good weather and just about every stream in the eastern areas of New York, Connecticut, New Jersey and Pennsylvania will be in perfect condition, and the trout fishermen probably will turn out in numbers that will rival the opening-day crowds.

RALPH INGERSOLL'S "Top Secret," a personal history of the war in Europe from the spring of 1943 to the spring of 1945, is one of the most unbalanced, vigorous--and readable--battle pieces of the year.
French insistence that the RuhrRhineland be separated from Germany is holding back operation of the Allied Control Council plan for a peaceful German economy; and

WASHINGTON, April 17--In the fleeting moment of some goodweather day in July when the bombardier sets the trigger releasing the atomic bomb, seventysix aircraft of many types will weave an intricate twenty-mile pattern over the clustered target ships at Bikini Atoll, recording the data that may affect the future of naval power.
WASHINGTON, April 17--The Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company, in order to have additional capital stock available for debt retirement and for other corporate purposes, asked the Interstate ...

WASHINGTON, April 17--President Truman was urged today in a surplus property report submitted by Howard Bruce, wartime director of Army materiel, to sanction speeding up the liquidation of the war's left-overs so that twothirds of the estimated $32,000,000,000 worth of goods would be I sold by the end of this year.

Fashions characterized by a simplicity of line and adornment were shown yesterday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Madame et La Jeune Fille. The collection included custom-made and ready-to-wear clothes for late spring and summer wear.
CHICAGO, April 17--May rye turned reactionary today after an early upturn of 1 3/8 cents had carried the price to a new high record of $2.48 a bushel.

NORTH PLAINFIELD, N. J., April 17--C. Frank Schwep, chairman of the board of the Midcity Trust Company of Plainfield, which he had helped organize, and vice president and purchasing agent of the Ingersoll Rand Drill Company of Easton, Pa., and New York, died here today in his home at 20 Rockview Avenue of a heart attack.

LONDON, April 17-Despite further strenuous efforts on trie part of delegates from eastern European countries, led by the Yugoslav delegate, Dr. Ales Bebler, to get the appointment of a special United Nations committee to investigate conditions in refugee camps,

Plans to acquaint New York consumers with the possibility of an acute milk shortage and to bring pressure to bear on the Board of Health to maintain present milk distribution regulations in the hope of forestalling such a shortage were made yesterday at a meeting of the Milk Procurement Committee for New York City, at a meeting at the Cornish Arms Hotel, 311 West Twentythird Street.
WASHINGTON, April 17--The clash between Representative Clare Boothe Luce and the Daughters of the American Revolution over al leged racial discrimination by the organization flared out again to day.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced last night that he would recommend to the Board of Estimate, at an executive meeting at City Hall this morning, an "upward revision" of the salaries of thousands of city employes for whom inadequate provision, or no provision at all, was made in the executive budget of $857,131,849 for 1946-47 submitted by him to the board on April 1.

ATHENS, April 17 (U.P.)--Herbert Hoover said today that the only way to prevent a next-to-starvation diet for millions of Greeks was to divert 100,000 tons of cereals en route from Canada to the United Kingdom.

LONDON, April 17-The fourpower commission of experts that visited Venezia Giulia has failed in its efforts to draw up a unanimous report on Trieste and the Italian-Yugoslav frontier in time for presentation to the deputies of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

With behind-the-scenes rumblings of a strike of grooms and exercise boys that threatens to shut down New York racing next week, and an on-the-track spill that sent Jockey George South to a hospital, a fair-to-middling card drew 32, ...
The Civilian Production Administration yesterday requested the Office of Price Administration to grant an immediate production incentive payment of 10 per cent to producers of northeastern hard- ...

Parents in the Queensbridge Housing Development, Long Island City, declared they were "temporarily satisfied" after an announcement last night by Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade that the housing project's community center building would be opened on May 1 as a school for children in the kindergarten through 3-B grades.

BOSTON, April 17--Lanky Hank Behrman, the kid from Maspeth, L. I., won himself a steady job today when he went the distance in his first major league start and the Dodgers beat the Braves, 4-2. A crowd of 11,270 saw the game.

Andrei A. Gromyko, Russia's representative on the United Nations Security Council, proposed yesterday that a session of the Council be held on Good Friday, but he was vetoed after the Brazilian delegate, Dr. Pedro Leao Velloso, said that his religious convictions and those of his country would not permit him to take part in such a session.

NUREMBERG, Germany, April 17--Admission after admission fell from the lips of Dr. Alfred Rosenberg today as the United States prosecutor, Thomas J. Dodd, destroyed the Nazi philosopher's selfportrait as a kindly benefactor and forced the German to admit responsibility for the Nazi regime in the plundered and devastated lands of Nazi-occupied Eastern Europe.

The Allied Council for Japan, consisting of representatives of the United States, Russia, China and the British Empire, was created at the last Foreign Ministers conference in Moscow. It was set up as a supplementary organ of the eleven-nation Far Eastern Commission for the purpose of advising ...

At the annual meeting of stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday, Walter S. Gifford, president, told 400 persons at the three-hour session that the company was "as busy as can be with a record $2,000,000,000 construction program."

A radio facsimile machine no larger than a portable typewriter that "prints" a four-column "newspaper" at the rate of 500 words a minute as well as pictures and advertisements, and does it with excellent clarity when linked with an ordinary FM receiver attuned to an FM facsimile program, received its first post-war showing yesterday at the laboratory of Radio Inventions, Inc., 155 Perry Street.
The City College baseball team dropped highly regarded Fowlham down a notch in the standing of the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium by beating the Rams, 7--4.
Maritime union leaders who are followers of the Communist party line take "red-covered books" aboard our merchant vessels for American seamen to read, Basil

WASHINGTON, April 17--The end of the President's first year in the White House evoked many lists of his Legislative recommendations on which Congress has not acted. But little attention was paid to one item of potential importance as great as that of any other in the catalogue. This concerns the matter of Presidential succession.

We may not be able to find a fine filet mignon, a succulent lamb chop or, for that matter, an indifferent piece of stew meat, but we can have poultry, and we don't even have to go through the business of de-pin-feathering, singeing and cooking it.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 17--Mrs. Lucy Ludington Lambert of Greenwich, Conn., formerly of St. Louis, daughter of Elliot K. Ludington of New York and Westport, Conn., and the late Mrs. Ludington, was married here this afternoon to Theodore Bache

Easter blooms in greater variety than ever before, although a few species are in short supply, are finding ready buyers at prices that average about the same as last year, a tour of wholesale and retail flower marts disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 17--President Truman took steps today in conference with the Naval High Command to prevent further instances of what he termed "lobbying" by Navy officers on the Army-Navy unification program, enjoining all active officers from further public discussion of the plan etcept when called upon by appropriate Congressional committees.

SANOK, Poland, April 17--A strong, well-organized and elusive band of Ukrainian nationalists and German deserters, estimated at more than 3,000 under the leadership of a German colonel, in a fortnight have succeeded in transforming this sector of the Carpathian foothills of old Galicia into a virtual partisan stronghold.
The Senate has begun debate on the most important question in the field of foreign policy which has come before it since the United Nations Participation Bill.

WASHINGTON, April 17--Experts of the Federal Reserve Board predicted today in a report on the recent organization of the Bretton Woods institutions that probably no important country will permit "large disturbing capital movements in the future."

WASHINGTON, April 17--A delegation of twenty-seven from Midwestern local unions of the United Packing House Workers, affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations, came here today to demand "real" Government seizure of the packing plants or an investigation of what they contend is an artificially stimulated meat shortage.

SEATTLE, April 17 (AP)--Daily air shipments of hundreds of pounds of fresh foods and perishables are helping meet shortages in Alaska caused by a tie-up of the territory's ports by a longshoremen's strike.
The Office of Price Administration put Into practice yesterday a new policy governing eviction notices to tenants in buildings where the owners plan demolition for erection of new structures.

Poland presented yesterday a four-count indictment against Franco Spain as a cause of international friction and a threat to peace and called upon the United Nations Security Council to direct all member states to sever diplomatic relations with Spain.

Just to show the home folks that they had more resources at their command than a mere home run, the Giants, with Big Jawn Mize back in their line-up, gathered four meager singles at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

JERUSALEM, April 17--The general strike of Government employes in Palestine continued today, with negotiations going on in all quarters. There was no agreement tonight and the meetings will be continued tomorrow. Railroads, communications and virtually all Government functions are at a standstill.

Franco Spain was indicted on four counts as a source of international friction and a menace to peace and security at yesterday's meeting of the United Nations Security Council. Dr. Oscar Lange of Poland asked the Council to direct all member nations to sever diplomatic relations with Spain at once and was seconded by the French and Mexican delegates.

The role of the United States in the United Nations, international control of atomic energy and the length of time price and rent controls should be maintained are among issues included in the new National League of Women Voters questionnaire for Congressional candidates, it vc as announced yesterday.

More than 30 per cent of industry will use color scientifically in its plants by the end of the year and thereby promote greater production and insure greater safety among employes, L. E. Whitmoyer, sales technical adviser of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., told ...
CHICAGO, April 17--Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers CIO, sounded a warning to industry today of new wage increase demands if there were any broad price rises.

MEXICO CITY, April 17--Commissioner A. B. (Happy) Chandler's decision to suspend American, baseball players who jumped the, United States leagues to play in Mexico failed today to disturb the stars who recently joined the Mexican circuit.
The deadlock in the United Nations Security Council over the correct legal procedure in the Iranian case was unresolved at a late hour last night.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17-- Manager Joe McCarthy went to the post with two of his freshman pitchers today with results that were something less than gratifying. The unpredictable Athletics turned unconventional, did everything contrary to baseball logic and swamped the Yankees before 11,901 fans by 7 to 1.
Magistrate J. Roland Sala described as "arrogant and stupid" the ticketing of his automobile, which he left in a no-parking strip in front of Mid-Manhattan Court on East Fifty-seventh Street.

A meeting of the board of directors of Panhandle Producing and Refining Company held here yesterday afternoon adjourned to a date "to be determined" without taking any action, according to Serge Rubinstein, president and chairman. Financial circles had forecast Mr. Rubinstein's resignation at that meeting.

ATHENS, Greece, April 17 (AP) -Constantin Tsaldaris--a strong proponent of an immediate plebiscite on the question of the return of King George II to the Greek throne--proceeded to form a new Government tonight after Premier Panayotis--Poulitsas and three leaders of the National Bloc resigned.

Two hundred and twenty-two residents of the East New York and Brownsville sections of Brooklyn were fined a total of $1,021 in the East New York Magistrate's Court yesterday and ninety-two other men and women--making the day's total 314--were fined ...

The opening date of "Swan Song" at the Booth is now definite. Jot it down for Saturday night, May 11. Incidentally, Lou Cooper, one of the composers of "Tidbits of '46," has written some satirical musical strains for the use of Jacqueline Horner, 12-yearold pianist, who will appear in the play.

To obtain trimmer uniforms for women in the armed forces, the Quartermaster Corps is conducting a nation-wide survey of the young American female figure for the styling of Wac and nurse uniforms, Col. Simon Jacobson.
Following are excerpts from the provisional official text of remarks of delegates at the Security Council meeting yesterday:

VIENNA, April 17-The amputation of Austria from the German economy is directly responsible for a large part of the catastrophic economic situation here, and the resumption of German-Austrian trade is an economic necessity of the first order, according to reports made to the American High Command in Austria by its economic and commercial experts.

Jake Weber, veteran trainer now serving at New York University, and Fred Sickinger, Manhattan College's middle distance star, were honored at a luncheon of the New York Track Writers Association at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22--The meetings here of the Far Eastern Commission are held in deep secrecy, a condition brought about by the insistence of some of its members (not the representatives of the United States).

WASHINGTON, April 22--An alien cannot be denied United States citizenship on grounds that if naturalized he would not bear arms in the country's defense, the Supreme Court ruled today in a 5 to 3 decision.

ROSCOE, N.Y., April 22--Although the week-end provided excellent fly fishing on both the Willowemoc and the Beaverkill it was apparent that the pressure from home was stronger than the fishing urge for many a New York City angler who appeared on these streams Saturday routed out early Sunday for the return to the Easter parade.
It has nothing to do with the black market, but the New York Zoological Society is looking forward in the next few days to the arrival of two Guatemalan wild turkeys that are valued at $25 a pound.

A return to the "homey" methods of the old family doctor has been effected in the modern impersonal medical age through the Department of Physical Medicine at Bellevue Hospital, it was reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22--It took the Giants quite a spell today to shake off the jarring effects of their recent misadventures in Brooklyn but once they became cognizant of the fact that those terrifying Dodgers were no longer buzzing in their ears they moved out of their "transom" quite nicely.

TOKYO, April 22--The Government of Premier Baron Kijuro Shidehara resigned en bloc this afternoon after twelve days of political maneuvering following the general election. It had been proved that the Cabinet was unable to remain in office in the face ...

LONDON, April 22 (Canadian Press)--Charlton Athletic, cup finalist and leader of the Football League South, now shares the league lead with Birmingham City as a result of today's holiday games.
The State of Louisiana will receive bids until May 27 on $4,622,000 of institutional bonds dated May 1, 1946, and due on each May 1 from 1950 to 1957.

A new housing development to provide living quarters for 4,000 United Nations employes and their families is "almost ready to get going" in the vicinity of Queens General Hospital in Jamaica and should be ready for occupancy by Jan. 1, it was indicated yesterday by Mayor William O'Dwyer during a press conference in City Hall.

Gross operating income of the Gulf Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries was at a record high in 1945 and the consolidated net profit increased more than $3,000,000 over 1944, according to the company's thirty-eighth annual report, which is being mailed to stockholders today.

Hollywood is clamoring for Walter Huston's services in "Ah, Wilderness!" Such a stentorian call, amplified by persuasive decibels, just can't be ignored, not even by a rugged individualist like Mr. Huston. Consequently, the star says he is forced to detach himself ...

The United Nations Security Council, meeting at 3 P.M. today after a long Easter recess, will plunge at once into another bitter debate demonstrating Big Three disunity on the Iranian issue, and then will seek to find common ground for authorizing an inquiry as to whether the Franco regime in Spain is a threat to peace.
BURLINGTON, Vt., April 22-- Former United States District Court Judge Harland Bradley Howe died here today after a brief illness. He was 73 years old.

Samuel E. Magid, vice president of Hill, Thompson Co., of this city, has been elected a director of General Products Corporation of New Jersey. Mr. Magid also is a director of Empire Steel Corporation and other industrial concerns.

WASHINGTON, April 22--Senator Arthur Vandenberg, generally recognized as Republican party spokesman on foreign affairs in the Senate, endorsed the $3,750,000,000 credit to Great Britain today on grounds of "intelligent ...

WASHINGTON, April 22--Two specks of light relieved an otherwise bleak outlook for foreign food relief today as President Truman told Congress that the months ahead were critical and the producing countries must not fail in their obligations.

LONDON, April 22--From the vantage point of an industry that is fairly certain of escaping nationalization, the Liverpool Steamship Owners Association, representing the bulk of the British shipping industry, in a report to be presented at the annual meeting on Thursday, makes a vigorous attack ...

The twelve-story Hotel Ransby at 324 West Eighty-fourth Street has been leased for five years by the Soviet Purchasing Commission, 210 Madison Avenue, as a housing center for its employes in the New York area, it was disclosed yesterday.

MILAN, Italy, April 22 (AP)-- Holding army and police units at bay with light machine guns and grenades, 2,500 prisoners in Milan's huge San Vittore Jail threatened tonight to hang ten of the guards captured as hostages during a revolt which began yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22--F.H. La Guardia, Director-General of United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, called upon soft coal operators and the United Mine Workers today "in the name of suffering humanity" to cooperate in supplying the coal that is necessary to save lives in Europe.

A maximum interval of three years, within which every room of a rented apartment or house must be redecorated, including painting or wallpaper, was adopted yesterday by the district Office of Price Administration.

PARIS, April 22--France's political campaign for the Constitution referendum opened full blast today. There were speeches, posters, party announcements and Deputies' surveys to test public opinion in all parts of the country.

A total of 561,444 calls at homes were made in 1945 by the three visiting nurse agencies of Greater New York, Miss Marian G. Randall, executive director of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, announced yesterday at its headquarters, 262 Madison Avenue.

LONDON, April 22--A unanimous report of the Anglo-American Committee of Inquiry on Jewish problems has recommended that 100,000 Jews from Europe be admitted to Palestine as quickly as possible, it was learned tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 --Ida Lupino has been signed by Benedict Bogeaus for the starring lead in "The Affair of the Diamond Necklace," a screen story by Ladislas Fodor and Rose Simon Kohn, dealing with a court incident during the reign of King Louis XVI ...

Former Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts urged Washington yesterday to take the lead in calling an international conference for organization of a world government to outlaw war and regulate armaments.

The marriage of Mrs. Michelle Bouvier Scott, daughter of John Vernou Bouvier of 765 Park Avenue and the late Mrs. Bouvier, to Harrington Putnam of 411 East Fifty-first Street, son of Mrs. Harrington Putnam of 225 East Fifty-fourth Street and the late Mr. Putnam, one-time Justice of ...

MUNICH, Germany, April 22-- With its faculty purged of Nazi party members, Munich University still is a center of German nationalism and militarism where subjects dear to the Nazis are taught and students openly refer to Americans as the "enemy."

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 22-- Edward A. Lyman of 9 Midland Gardens, this place, editor of the Letters to the Editor department Of THE NEW YORK TIMES and a member of the news staff of the newspaper for more than twentyone years, died here this morning in Lawrence Hospital after a week's illness. His age was 69.
TRENTON, N.J., April 22--A Federal penitentiary sentence of five years for embezzlement was imposed today in Federal District Court on Miss Ann T. Callahan, 52-year-old Trenton bank employe.
MADRID, April 22--Two guerrilla raids, in one of which a wealthy property owner was killed in the presence of his wife and son, were unofficially reported here today.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 22 (AP)--Land 'N Sea, R.A. Petillo's 3-year-old Equestrian gelding made a show of his field at Narragansett Park today while winning the mile and seventy-yard feature event with twelve lengths to spare on the Victory Stable's Jellico.

WASHINGTON, April 22--The Swiss Government has agreed to limit exportation of watches and movements to the United States in 1946 to the same amount that was directly exported here in 1945, the State Department announced today. The Swiss will also prevent indirect shipments to the United States, passing through third countries.

"JUST a light novel, one that's amusing and clever and intelligent, that's all I want." How frequently does this plaintive cry sound in the ears of those engaged in any branch of the literary business! But most supposedly light novels are broad and foolish farces or syrupy conventional romances. More people want good light novels than get them.

Problems of the smaller daily newspapers will be the first to come up for discussion as the sixtieth annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association opens today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Public attention with relation to United Nations activities in the United States has been focused almost exclusively upon the dramatic sessions of the Security Council at Hunter College and the efforts of the United Nations to find interim and permanent homes.

HARTSVILLE, S.C., April 22-- Mrs. David R. Coker of this place has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Mary, to Lieut. William Joslin, USNR, son of Mrs. Harold Vincent Joslin of Raleigh, N.C., and the late Mr. Joslin. The wedding will take place here on the afternoon of May 18.

LONDON, April 22--When the conference of British Dominions Foreign Ministers opens here tomorrow morning one of the first topics of their conversations will be the American desire for permanent bases in the Pacific Islands.

The American Bankers Association made public yesterday a fourpoint program against inflation adopted at a recent meeting of its executive council, setting forth national monetary policies considered necessary to the avoidance of further inflation.
Alden C. Olander has been appointed retail merchandising manager of Bendix Home Appliance, Inc., South Bend, Ind.

The nation's women were chided yesterday by Fannie Hurst, author, for allowing last week's legislation on the Office of Price Administration to be passed by the House of Representatives. She spoke at the annual spring luncheon of the New York City Society of Kentucky Women at the Hotel Vanderbilt.

Grove Properties, Inc., of which Edward H. Benenson is president, has purchased the five-story business building at 125 Fifth Avenue from Marvin S. Winter through Arthur I. Goldman, broker. The property, assessed at $90,000, occupies a plot 45 by 100 feet in the block between Nineteenth and Twentieth Street.
PARIS, April 12--For some time fashion reporters have been talking about wasp waists, but has anyone seen any? Most of them are very thickish, indeed.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- When Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg returned to Washington from the United Nations General Assembly meeting in London last February, his general attiude toward trips in support of the Administration's foreign policy was: "Never again!"

INNSBRUCK, Austria, April 22 --The Austrian Government will appeal to each of the member governments of the United Nations to support the return of South Tyrol from Italy to Austria, it was announced here today. Austria, it was learned, seeks to have the matter brought before the United Nations for discussion.

The Federal drive against black market meat in the New York area will be broadened and intensified with the complete cooperation of all the enforcement agencies of the city, United States Attorney General Tom C. Clark announced yesterday after a conference with Mayor O'Dwyer and other officials.

The market news reporter at the local office of the United States Department of Agriculture said yesterday that fresh green peas were an excellent selection at the moment both from the angle of economy and flavor. Spring, it seems, is the very best time of ...
TEHERAN, Iran, April 22 (AP)-- Premier Ahmad Ghavam announced today in a communique a seven-point proposal under which Azerbaijan Province might return to the Iranian National Government.
Pericles, pride and joy of William Helis, yesterday made his long over-due installment payment on the $66,000 investment the Greek sportsman made in him three years ago when he was a yearling.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) is on the side of human freedom and opposed to expanding authority of the State, according to a "statement of principles" published yesterday as a foreword to the annual report for 1945 and signed by the directors of the company.

NEW DELHI, India, April 22-- Sir Robert Hutchings, Secretary of the Government of India's Food Department, said today India's slender rationing system could not continue beyond June 30 unless substantial food shipments from abroad arrived promptly.

New York City is experiencing its driest year on record, with a rainfall of only 7.35 inches for the period from Jan. 1 to April 22, it was revealed yesterday by Benjamin Parry, chief meteorologist of the city's weather bureau. He explained that the bureau, established in 1871, had recorded only one comparable dry spell--in 1927, when the rainfall for the same period was 9.12 inches.
Cotton futures fluctuated over a wide range yesterday and closed unchanged to 29 points net lower than last week's final prices.

MANILA, Tuesday, April 23 (AP) --Filipinos went to the polls today to elect a President and a slate of officers to lead the Philippine Republic to be inaugurated next July 4. Nearly 3,000,000 voters were eligible to cast ballots.

All five sons and the daughter of John D. Rockefeller Jr. have formed a limited partnership with an initial capital of $1,500,000 to engage in "the finding, investigation and financing of new, productive and constructive businesses and projects, the making of permanent or long-term investments and the management and supervision of such investments."

PHILADELPHIA, April 22--A group of common stockholders of Northern States Power Company (Del.), composed of Lehman Brothers, Riter Co., Lehman Corporation and the Overseas Securities Company, Inc, representing 18.44 per cent of the company's class A ...

Overruling a vigorous protest by a militant minority, the Medical Society of the County of New York adopted a resolution last night opposing national compulsory health insurance at its monthly meeting at the Academy of Medicine 103d Street and Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 22--Kenneth C. Royall, Under Secretary of War, said today that the Army had taken steps to dispose of $11,410,000,000, or 74 per cent, of the $15,340,000,000 of its surplus materiel overseas, and predicted that it would clean up the rest of the job, except for guard duty, by mid-summer.

Directors of the American Viscose Corporation and of Sylvania Industrial Corporation voted at separate meetings yesterday to approve a plan for acquisition of all property and assets of Sylvania in exchange for 327,411 common shares of Viscose.

New York's bread basket was well stocked yesterday, the first effective day of the national 25 per cent wheat-saving order, with business as usual in most shops and bakeries. There was no reduction in the output of the major bakeries, and only a few retailers found any cut in the deliveries made to them.

The resistance level of the stock market was lowered further yesterday under increased offerings. Except for a few sections of the list final prices were on the lower side despite a modest recovery which developed late in the session.

CHICAGO, April 23--May rye closed today with a net gain of 5 cents a bushel, the limit for a day on the Board of Trade, after being down 5 cents at one time early, having a range of 10 cents. Its fluctuations were the most erratic that has been witnessed in any grain in many months.

CHICAGO, April 23--Increased consumer goods sales will be accompanied by a corresponding increase in the demand for consumer credit, credit men attending the annual conference of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association were told today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated yesterday over a moderate range and closed 17 to 25 points net higher than on Monday.

LONDON, April 23--The British Dominions conference jumped headlong this morning into a discussion of the European peace treaties and world politics without losing any time on the formalities that had been planned.

Manufacturers of plastics materials can supply only about onethird of the present demand, although they are operating plants at capacity and have doubled their 1941 output, W. Stuart Landes, president of the Plastic Materials Manufacturers Association, said yesterday.

Although the housing shortage will make May 1 only a pale memory of the traditional "moving day," enough families and business concerns that are going to new quarters this season have protested against the fees charged by moving men to induce a warning by the Office of Price Administration to the moving van operators.
BUFFALO, April 23 (AP)--Frank X. Schwab, former brewer, who served two terms as Mayor of Buffalo, died of a heart ailment today at the age of 71.

WASHINGTON, April 23-- Manufacturers of cutting tools and attachments and accessories for machinery and machine tools were granted today a price increase of 17.3 per cent above the levels of March 31, 1942, by the Office of Price Administration.

Christopher G. Sotiro has returned from the service to take his place beside his father in the family's shop, The House of Yemen Coffee, the third generation of Sotiros to blend, roast and sell America's favorite beverage.

MILAN, Italy, April 23--Swift, expert grave robbers dug the remains of Benito Mussolini from his unmarked pauper's grave, a municipal communique said today. Officials disclosed a letter that said the body had been taken by the "Democratic Fascist party."

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)-- Robert R. Wason, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, testified today that the Office of Price Administration had had "nothing to do with production except to prevent it."

WASHINGTON, April 23--It was confidently predicted by informed officials today that by the time American experts had finished their meticulous appraisal of the carefully prepared French case for dollar credits of $4,000,000,000, ...

CHUNGKING, April 23--The planes that strafed Communist troops at Szepingkai last week were Chinese Government aircraft and not American, a report received here today and released from Gen. George C. Marshall's headquarters, indicates.

Sylvester Gilbert Whiton, a general insurance broker, decorated veteran of the first World War, prominent Mason and Episcopal layman, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home, 689 East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Whiton's office was at 111 Fulton Street. His age was 50.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 23--Merger of the United Federal Workers of America, CIO, and the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, CIO, was completed here shortly before midnight tonight by unanimous vote of the latter group.

LONDON, April 23--With buying orders accumulating over the Easter holiday for Orange Free State gold shares further sharp rises--accompanied by wild fluctuations as profits were taken--were seen when the stock markets opened today. Most brokers were at their offices early and in early dealings conditions were even more hectic than during last week's boom.

Recent elections in many parts of Europe have demonstrated that despite two world wars and the tidal waves of totalitarian systems of the Right and Left, democracy is still very much alive on that continent. But it may be doubted that democracy can survive anywhere in continental Europe unless it survives in France, which cradled it and became the model and inspiration for many European nations.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 23-- Led by Ralph Tate, war hero who ran and jumped his way to impressive victories over the high and low hurdles and in the broad jump, Oklahoma A. and M. defeated Army's track and field stalwarts today, 8 to 6 , on the military academy's track overlooking the Hudson. Only first places counted in the scoring.

TOKYO, April 23--Baron Kijuro Shidehara, who resigned last night as Premier, today continued his attempt to form a coalition government. He interviewed leaders of the Liberal and Socialist parties. He is understood to have promised the support of his own Progressive party in any three-party coalition that could be arranged.

The city's meat supply, which has been choked up in wholesale houses or diverted to restaurants, will begin today to flow a little more freely to retail outlets, Leo F. Gentner, regional head of the Office of Price Administration, predicted last night.

A new type of ballet company made its debut last night at the Children's Aid Society Sloane Center at 630 East Sixth Street with ballerinas ranging in age from 6 to 8. Whirling through a "dance of the flowers" in the center's spring play, "Sleeping Beauty," the premiere danseuses, trained ...

[In 1942 Ambassador Hoare made a tour of Spanish cities during which he obtained firsthand information on Franco's hostility to any independence on the part of the Catholic Church in Spain. He describes below a visit to the monks of the Abbey of Montserrat, near Barcelona.]

CLEVELAND, April 23--Representatives of government, management and labor from twelve nations, convened here in the City Hall's council chamber today as members of the International Labor Office met for the first time to improve working, living and social standards in the iron and steel industry throughout the world.

EL PASO, Tex., April 23 (AP)-- The baseball ambitions of the wealthy Pasquels not only have been a headache to big league clubs in the United States but now they are making inroads on a rival league in Mexico--the Mexican National.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 23 (AP)--Ed Gravely, 25-year-old linksman, fought an uphill battle through four extra holes to eliminate former national amateur champion Richard D. Chapman in the first round of the North and South amateur golf championship here today.

Although new calls were voiced last night by Americans urging the United Nations to begin work at once on the establishment of international control of atomic energy, the Atomic Energy Commission still lacked representatives of the Soviet Union and Mexico.

ALBANY, April 23--Governor Dewey approved today a general recodification of the multiple dwelling law, but vetoed several separate bills to relax its standards so as to permit using of space which cannot now be rented for residence purposes.

CINCINNATI, April 23 (AP)--The Cardinals spurted for two runs in the eighth inning today to defeat the Reds, 3--2, for their second successive victory of a three-game series. The Redlegs got both runs by way of circuit clouts.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 23--As Vassar College reopened today for its third term, thirty-six war veterans from the local community were enrolled with the women students.

The first annual award of the National Newspaper Promotion Association was made last night. Mark Ethridge, published of The Louisville Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times, was named as the publisher who "gave the greatest recognition to the importance of promotion and used its forces to the highest extent for organizatian progress and public benefit."

Four of the country's leading court tennis players will appear in an exhibition doubles match for the benefit of the American Red Cross on Friday afternoon at the Racquet and Tennis Club on Park Avenue.

RICHMOND, Va., April 23 (AP)-- Stockholders of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company approved today a merger of the Pere Marquette Railway Company with the C. at their annual meeting. Holders of 4,538,446 shares voted in favor of the merger and holders of 51,785 shares voted against it.

WASHINGTON, April 23--Funeral services for Chief Justice Harlan Fiske Stone, who died yesterday, will be held at 2 P.M. Thursday in the Washington Cathedral. Burial will be in a yet undesignated cemetery in this city.

The five-story business building at 21 West Thirty-fifth Street, held at $60,000, was sold by the trustees of St. Patrick's Cathedral to Mesaba Construction Corporation through John J. Reynolds, broker. Samuel W. Cracowaner represented the purchaser; Gillespie O'Connor, the sellers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23-- The North West Utilities Company and its parent, the Middle West Corporation, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan covering the dissolution of North West, as ordered by the commission in 1943, and the distribution of its assets to its capital stockholders.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 23 (AP)-- Premier Ahmad Ghavam announced today he had sent an emissary to Azerbaijan to invite representatives of that self-proclaimed autonomous Government to discussions in Teheran on returning the province to central Government control.
YONKERS, N.Y., April 23--Dr. John Franklin Reigart of 31 Euclid Avenue, civic leader and retired educator, died yesterday in Yonkers Professional Hospital after a three-day illness. His age was 82.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 23--Argentina has made considerable progress in lining up a bloc in southern South America that is cooperating closely on political and economic matters and that has as one of its unwritten policies opposition to the United States.

A complete reorganization of volunteer groups in hospitals to a peacetime level must be made before fresh groups of volunteers are recruited, Raymond P. Sloan, editor of the magazine Modern Hospital, declared yesterday at the United Hospital Fund of New York, 370 Lexington Avenue.

Fashions in which to keep cool and attractive in the approaching summer months were presented yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton by Macy's. There were frocks for town, play clothes for lively vacations, and a collection of romantic evening gowns to round out the picture.
The Dutch printing industry, from whose presses there issued during the German occupation a torrent of illegal newspapers, forged identification papers and counterfeit ration booklets, is today ...

WASHINGTON, April 23--The Washington Literary Society, oldest organization of its kind in the District of Columbia, held its usual monthly meeting last Saturday night, and the Chief Justice of the United States never appeared more fit or more interested in the discussion.

MUNICH, Germany, April 23--The Landkreis [county] of Miesbach, which spreads itself at the foot of the Bavarian Alps, is typical of those rural communities that the Nazis favored as sites for their country homes.

The one-story taxpayer with five stores at 5501-11 New Utrecht Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by Sarah Kostman to Herbaun Realty Corporation through Charles Gonickman, broker; and the threestory building at 1035 Rutland Road was purchased by Harry Chaess from Julius Jacknowitz et al. City Title Insurance Company insured both titles.

The Soviet union lost yesterday its bitter battle for immediate removal of the Iranian case from the United Nations Security Council agenda, and served notice at once that it would not participate in any future international consideration of the Iranian question.

Doubt that the American people generally really can comprehend the gravity of the food crisis in Europe was expressed yesterday by James A. Farley in an interview in which he gave his observations on an eight-week business trip abroad that ended last Saturday.

Leo Durocher, the 39-year-old manager of the Brooklyn baseball club, threw many punches at John Christian, 23, the veteran who charges him with fracturing his jaw, but the blows were well blocked, according to testimony yesterday in Kings County Court during the second-degree assault trial of the Dodger leader.

A one-man show of sculpture and drawings by Maria, wife of Carlos Martins, the Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, opened with an invitation preview yesterday afternoon at the Valentine Gallery, 55 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The Eversharp "CA" Repeater Pen with the "magic sphere," shown at a press conference yesterday, will be backed by the most powerful advertising campaign in the history of the industry, it was announced.

Quite a procession of post-Easter departures is in the offing. The latest closing, announced for May 4, is "I Like It Here," starring Oscar Karlweis and Bert Lytell. Although the critics didn't do any handstands over the A.B. Shiffrin comedy, there was no room for any argument concerning Mr. Karlweis' contribution.

VIENNA, Austria, April 23 (AP) --President Karl Renner suggested to fourteen American editors and publishers visiting Vienna today that the occupation of Austria, now conducted by four powers, be turned over to a force of international troops under United Nations command.
WASHINGTON, April 23--With ship disposal under the Ship Sales Act in its second day, the United States Maritime Commission and the shipping industry are seeking safeguards against foreign buyers ...
WASHINGTON, April 23--The State Department announced today that in response to representations made in Teheran against the reported censorship of foreign ...
LONDON, April 23--United States Ambassador John G. Winani received a remarkable tribute tonight from some of those who worked with him in the difficult years of the war.

PARIS, April 23--Importation groups composed of representatives of private industry are being formed under the direction of the French Government to replace the French Purchasing Commissions in the United States and Great Britain, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, April 23--R.J. Thomas, unseated president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, threw down a challenge today to possibly the most bitter battle within the American labor movement since John L. Lewis led a cecession from the American Federation of Labor.

Rare books of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries brought substantial prices last night when Part Three of the Frank J. Hogan library was sold at auction in the first of two sessions at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 30 East Fiftyseventh Street. Proceeds from the session came to $81,290.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 23--With the nation now experiencing a serious beer shortage, the Army and Navy were charged today with hoarding several hundred thousand cases of beer in public storage warehouses throughout the country.

Establishment of a State university in New York through the immediate utilization of a network of existing collegiate and graduate institutions was advocated yesterday by Henry Epstein, former Solicitor General of New York.

Nathan Wilson, real estate operator, has purchased the threestory business and apartment building at 300 East 204th Street, southeast corner of Perry Avenue, the Bronx, from Charles Charcowsky of Miami, Fla. The 204th Street Postoffice branch occupies a portion of the ground floor on the Perry Avenue side of the building, which contains six stores and four apartments.
Removal of price controls to release an oversupply of specified automotive parts and accessories and smash any black-market dealings throughout the country was urged yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate were urged yesterday by eight members of the minority in the City Council to restore cuts in the 1946-47 budget to provide funds for the expansion of the nursery and child-care program of the Welfare Department and for the continuance of the nutritional division of the Health Department.

Metropolitan racegoers, 30,576 of them, yesterday saw something as rare as, if not rarer than, Lowell's day in June. They saw Stymie, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' wonder horse, second-best handicap horse in the land last year, beaten and beaten rather decisively.

A majority of eight members of the United Nations Security Council yesterday stood firm on the important principle that a problem once brought to the Council's attention cannot be considered closed merely because a complaining state withdraws its complaint.

CHUNGKING, April 23--The efforts of Gen. George C. Marshall to mediate in the KuomintangCommunist dispute are believed to have reached an advanced stage here today. Following protracted discussions yesterday with Gen. Chou En-lai, Communist leader, and President Chiang Kai-shek, General Marshall saw the two separately again today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 23 --Although the Communist party obtained only 17 per cent of the vote in the Hungarian general elections last November, Communist control of the present Hungarian Government has become in recent weeks fairly complete.
NUREMBERG, Germany, April 23 (AP)--An affidavit by the SS [Elite Guard] general who crushed the Warsaw revolt said today Dr. Hans Frank was denounced by Heinrich Himmler, Gestapo chief, ...

WASHINGTON, April 23--Velocity modulation, a revolutionary development in radio transmission brought about by wartime research, was described here today before the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences by Dr. O.E. Buckley, president of the Bell Telephone Laboratories.

Mr. Kluckhohn's dispatch from Montevideo to this newspaper reports the pressure being brought to bear on Uruguay by the Argentine Government because Uruguay has been steadfast in its devotion to democratic principles.

New York City, seeking 10,000 new apartments through rehabilitation of boarded-up buildings, will increase pressure on owners of tenement houses by more frequent foreclosure of tax-delinquent properties, it was learned yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 24--Russian authorities today gave the United States Embassy permission to increase the circulation of the magazine America from its present 20,000 copies monthly to 50,000. On the basis of this new circulation America can become self-supporting.

VIENNA, April 24--A second unarmed United States plane has been shot at by Russian fliers, it was disclosed today. This second attack, which also has been protested by Gen. Mark W. Clark, commander of United States forces in Austria, took place first in order of time.

The four-story rooming house with three-story extension at 42 West Seventy-sixth Street has been purchased by M.C. Berg, operator, through Slawson Hobbs, brokers. It was acquired subject to a first mortgage of $19,000 and is assessed at $29,000.

NEWARK, N.J., April 24--Robert L. Ross, retired president of the Franklin Savings Institution, who was president of the Essex County Sinking Fund, died last night of a heart attack, at the age of 80, while dining in a restaurant here with his daughter, Mrs. E. R. Trowbridge, who lives at the Robert Treat Hotel.

CINCINNATI, April 24 (AP)--The Reds have yet to win a home game this season. Today's encounter with the Cardinals, which they lost, 3--2, made it six defeats in a row at Crosley Field and also marked the Redbirds' seventh straight triumph.

The Port of New York Authority, which was established twenty-five years ago tomorrow, has spent $240,000,000 during that time in developing transportation and terminal facilities in the port and has made plans for further construction and improvement, it was announced yesterday.

Everything has been set in motion by Jacob Freidus, spectacular 32-year-old real estate operator, to purchase the venerable Empire Theatre and the adjoining property at the southeast corner of Broadway and Fortieth Street for $1,000,000.

Dependent and neglected children should receive for at least their first six years the foster care that only substitute mothers could give, according to Dr. Lauretta Bender, senior psychiatrist at Bellevue Hospital. She spoke yesterday at a luncheon arranged by the division on child care of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

The mountain wouldn't go to Mohammed so there was nothing for Mohammed to do but come to the mountain which is just another way of saying that the much-publicized match between Byron Nelson, America's premier golfer, and Richard (Dick) Burton, British open champion, is on.

In the course of the public discussions concerning wage policy last winter it was pointed out frequently that there were limits beyond which wages could not be increased without the necessity of raising prices. In most of its negotiations the AFL kept this factor in mind. The CIO, on the other hand, particularly the UAW, insisted that large wage increases could take place without price increases.

The Raleigh, a seven-story apartment house on a plot 84 by 100 feet at 7 West Ninety-second Street has been sold by the Vanpark Realty Corporation to Rosemont Realties, Inc., in a deal arranged by Joe G. Fine, broker. It contains forty-two apartments and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $123,200. Harry J. Fine was the attorney for the seller and Edward Fingerman for the buyer.
Lentheric, Inc., in a deal reported to involve $1,425,000, has purchased the former Ford building at 32-14 Northern Boulevard, Long Island City, Queens.

The lengthening shadows of industrial disruption due to the prolonged coal strike caused buyers yesterday to defer activity on the Stock Exchange, and, except for a handful of special situations, prices softened. Irregularity during the morning gave way to a moderate decline in the afternoon. Although pressure at no time assumed major proportions, stocks backed down from lack of supporting bids.

The New York Stock Exchange, which became a surprise contender on Tuesday for a real place in the United States Government bond market by ignoring an overcounter rule against daily fluctuations of more than 8/32 point, was doing a reduced but very brisk business in Treasuries yesterday. Turnover in bonds on the Exchange was $2,920,000, less than ...

All eight originally seeded teamsof-four in the Vanderbilt Cup bridge tournament were in the first knockout round at the Hotel Pierre last night, survivors of the two qualifying sessions held Monday and Tuesday. The tournament's present field of sixteen teams will be reduced to eight in tonight's quarter-finals, reduced by one-half again tomorrow, and will end Saturday evening with two teams in the finals.

Seven hundred persons, including many fellow-explorers of the Arctic, attended yesterday a funeral service at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, for Capt. Robert A. (Bob) Bartlett, who died Sunday in the Harkness Pavilion, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, at the age of 70. The mourners included Matt Henson, the Negro steward of Peary's ship, who was with Peary at the North Pole.

Raising the status of women internationally "to equality with man in all fields of human endeavor" is the purpose of the Subcorrimission on the Status of Woman of the Commission on Human Rights of the Economic Social Council of the United Nations, a resolution adopted by the subcommission yesterday asserted.

Those of you who dream of taking a three-pound squaretail will have an opportunity to enjoy a real nightmare by going up to Long Lake, in Maine's Belgrade Lakes area, and duplicating the pleasant experience of Ben Luce of Oakland, Me., who brought in a six-pound twelve-ounce specimen.

PITTSBURGH, May 1--Everchanging conditions have reacted to the disadvantage of Pittsburgh as a steel center, which is now unable to reach many markets profitably, and the city must look to a greater diversification of local industry to offset this, J.L. Perry, president of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, said before the Institute on Community Problems at the University of Pittsburgh today.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The Office of Price Administration announced today that it has extended the voluntary mark-up period for men's clothing manufacturers under the maximum average price regulation for thirty days.

Although elimination of the Maximum Average Price provision in the new Price Control Act appears to be a certainty, manufacturers of textiles and apparel will be faced with an even more ruinous order of the same type to be promulgated by the Civilian Production Administration, Erwin Feldman, director-counsel of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 1-President John L. Lewis of the United Mine Workers unexpectedly summoned today his 250-member policy committee to meet here Tuesday. The action stirred speculation about a possible "break" in the seven-week-old soft coal negotiations.

ALBANY, May 1--Representatives of ten colleges and universities in the State met here today and decided on favoring establishment of a single corporation to operate the suggested collegiate emergency centers at the Sampson ...

DETROIT, May 1-The legal department of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was ordered today by Walter P. Reuther, president of the union, to file a protest with the Office of Price Administration against what he called "second round" increases in the price of automobiles.

NANKING, May 1 (AP)--China's Government moved back officially today from Chungking to this ancient northern city and was confronted with problems almost as complex as those of 1937 when the Japanese drove it out of Nanking.

The leading "five and dime" chains expressed objections yesterday to half a dozen provisions of the State minimum wage order under which their women and minor male emgloyes have been earning 52 cents an hour since last November.

Fortune Gallo's San Carlo Opera Company opened its twelve-day season at the Center Theatre last night with a spirited performance of Yerdi's "Aida." All of the participants gave of their best in a presentation that moved along smoothly and aroused the enthusiasm of the capacity audience.

As a member of the United Nations, the United States has assumed the obligation to use its power and influence in collaboration with other nations to defend the peace against aggression or any threat of aggression. In the alliances now publicly proposed by Secretary Byrnes it is ready to assume even more specific obligations to safeguard ...

CHICAGO, May 1 (AP)--Rains came to some areas of the parched Western winter wheat belt today, reviving hopes that the area still would be able to produce a good crop. Heavy rains also occurred in the corn-growing lands of Central Illinois and Indiana.

MADRID, May 1--Generalissimo Francisco Franco last night made to the citizens of Albacete what many observers here consider to be a direct bid for his popular election as Chief of State. He said in a May Day speech that his regime had demonstrated fully its good faith.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 60 per cent in April, marking both the heaviest Easter trade and the largest percentage increase for any month in their history, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, May 1 The Army Air Forces plan a seacoast site for at least part of the proposed 100-square-mile development center for air engineering.
