HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1-- James Cagney will be starred by Twentieth Century-Fox in the lead of the Office of Strategic Services film, "13 Rue Madeleine." It will be the actor's first picture outside of his independent activity since he left Warner Brothers four years ago. In accepting this part, production of Cagney's United Artist film. "The Stray Lamb," which he ...

NUREMBERG, Germany, May 1 --Pointedly dissociating himself from his co-defendants, Hjalmar Schacht pictured himself today as the "no" man of the German Government who sought by all means to limit German rearmament once its criminal, aggressive intent had become clear.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (U.P.)-- Local draft boards have been asked to call up only 52,000 men this month, following failure to meet the bid April call for 125,000.
TOKYO, May 1--Perhaps half a million persons paraded today in Japan's first May Day celebration in more than forty years. Their banners demanded a seven-hour day and removal of the Shidehara ...

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 1 (AP) --With picket lines at its gates, Narragansett Park had to revise its horse racing program today but 450 pari-mutuel department employes, cause of a jurisdictional dispute between unions, worked at top speed while disposing of $1,058,044 worth of tickets to a crowd of 19,000.

Controversy over the proposed unification of the armed services continues in Congress. First, there were hearings held by the Senate Military Affairs Committee in which the scales were weighted in favor of the proponents. Now the Senate Naval Affairs Committee is conducting its own hearings, which probably will lean toward the Navy side. Why joint hearings could not have been held must be puzzling to many, as it is to us.

CHICAGO, May 1--Resumption of negotiations between railroad owners and the Brotherhoods of Locomotive Engineers and Trainmen, scheduled for this afternoon after a twenty-four-hour recess, was suddenly called off today, giving rise to speculation that the next session might be crucial in its relation to ultimate settlement of the national rail strike set by the two unions for May 18.

Thousands of war veterans in full uniform took the spotlight yesterday as the left wing of New York's labor movement held its first May Day parade in five years. Five hundred Army and Navy veterans, including fifty officers, ...

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1--As owner of ten shares of stock of the Standard Oil Company of California, Harold L. Ickes, former Secretary of the Interior, arrived here today prepared to battle with the management over reinstatement of his former Deputy Petroleum Administrator, Ralph K. Davies, and to raise the issue of "outside control" of the company at the annual stockholders' meeting tomorrow.

A syndicate of investors bought the twelve-story loft building at 229 West Thirty-sixth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, from David S. Meister, operator, in a deal negotiated by Spear Co., brokers. Assessed at $645,000, the property is 115.6 by 98.9 feet and contains three stores and lofts occupied by textile and sportswear manufacturers. Goodman and Mabel were the attorneys for the buyers.

GIBRALTAR, April 30 (Delayed) --The U.S.S. Missouri completed her unprecedented "show-the-flag" circuit of the Mediterranean this morning, and sailed from Tangier with Wallace Murray, former Ambassador to Iran and Mrs. Murray, who were permitted to travel on the naval vessel by special authorization, as passengers.

Purchase of town houses for occupancy were among East Side realty deals reported yesterday. A modern four-story house with garden at 170 East Ninety-third Street was sold by Baldwin Maull to a client of the Madison Realty Company in its first change of ownership in ten years.

LEONARDO, N.J., May 1-- Hampered by the loss of personnel records, the Navy today redoubled its efforts to learn the number of missing and injured in the triple explosion that blasted the destroyer escort Solar here yesterday, and revised its original estimate to seven missing and thirty-six injured and hospitalized. Yesterday the Navy gave these figures as five and thirty-five respectively.

While endorsing the recommendation of the Anglo-American Committee of Inquiry to admit 100,000 Jews into Palestine immediately, spokesmen for the principal Zionist groups in America criticized the committee yesterday ...

A new prefabricated house that follows a pleasant middle course between the most advanced modern theories on the one hand and hackneyed traditional designs on the other was exhibited in model form yesterday at the workshop of Donald Deskey Associates, designers, at 145 East Thirty-second Street.

The number of arraignments or cases received by the City's Magistrates Courts increased in the last year as compared with 1944 but the fine added to the city's treasury decreased, according to the annual report made public yesterday by Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger.

CHICAGO, May 1--It may have been a revamped line-up, more robust hitting, or the six-hit pitching of Hal Gregg that gave the Dodgers today's 5-1 victory over the Cubs and shot them back up into a first-place tie with the idle Cardinals.

Combined operations of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and its subsidiaries including Roxy Theatre, Inc. and National Theatres Corporation and all its subsidiaries resulted in a consolidated net profit for 1945 of $12,746,467, according to the pamphlet report issued to stockholders yesterday by Spyros P. Skouras, president.
Eternal War, 2-year-old son of Eternal Bull and the property of Allen T. Simmons, won yesterday's $13,650 Youthful Stakes, second event for the youngsters at Jamaica.

It is the people of New York City who lost in the City Planning Commission's vote of five to two yesterday against the zoning that would have taken most of the interurban buses out of crowded midtown Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The Administration bill for a merger of the armed forces on the principle recommended by President Truman was denounced today by his Secretary of the Navy, James Forrestal, as "based upon a major premise which is false."

Thirty-three office laborers employed by the United Nations Secretariat at Hunter College in the Bronx demanded yesterday that their weekly take-home pay of $28.20 be increased by $10 and threatened to take the "usual aclion" by noon Tuesday if this demand were refused.

An exhibition of ceremonial masks of primitive people ranging from New York's Iroquois Indians to natives of the South Seas was opened yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at Seventy-ninth Street, at a preview for the trustees and invited guests.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1-- Trainer Ben Jones, who sent out Lawrin, Whirlaway and Pensive to win the Kentucky Derby, will be sitting this one out.
LONDON, May 1--The British Commonwealth seems tonight to be solidly lined up against the French proposal to separate the Ruhr and the Rhineland from the rest of Germany and internationalize them.

Mrs. Arline B. Cole of 42 East Fifty-second Street has announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of her daughter, Jean, to Lieut. Col. Stephanus F. duToit Jr., RAF, eldest son of Mr. and Mrs. duToit of Johannesburg, South Africa. The wedding is planned for the end of June in London, where the prospective bridegroom is stationed as South African demobilization officer.

The part played in prejudice by feelings of weakness and the desire to get even is examined in a scientific study of maladjusted children made during the war, and just published by the American Journal of Orthopsychiatry.
LONDON, May 1--Stock markets here generally were much quieter today than yesterday, the only bright feature being a revival of interest in Argentine railway stocks.

PARIS, May 1--Secretary of State James F. Byrnes proposed to the Council of Foreign Ministers this morning that the present occupying forces in Austria be immediately reduced to 15,000 men from each army--Soviet, United States, British and French.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1--Frederick A. Plaisted, world's champion professional sculler in 1887 and former rowing coach at Bowdoin College and Yale, Harvard and Columbia Universities, died today in University Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 96.

BAD NAUHEIM, Germany, May 1 (U.P.)--Col. Irvin Schindler of Salt Lake City, Utah, shepherd of a flock of nineteen special "expediters" flown here from Washington for the Lichfield trials, admatted today that high War Department officials "want this trial over in a hurry and out of the newspapers."

LONDON, May 1--Great Britain, while welcoming the Anglo-American Committee's report on Palestine, will not carry it out single-handed and wants to know to what extent the United States is prepared to share the burden, Prime Minister Attlee told the House of Commons in a prepared statement today.

WASHINGTON, May 1--Hundreds of millions of dollars worth of surplus war machinery and supplies is being held overseas to aid in restoring the economies of Allied countries but is idle and deteriorating rather than being put to that use, the Senate Investigating Committee was told today.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 (U.P.) --William M. (Little Bill) Johnston, 51, former national tennis champion, died of a heart attack at his home here tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 1--By the time the national political conventions are held, two years and two months hence, the current list of eligibles in the major parties may have changed greatly.

PARIS, May 2--In an effort to come to an agreement with the French on the Ruhr, the British agreed today to a military occupation of the region "for many years" and to set up there a separate provincial administration loosely linked with the central government in Berlin but directly under the Allies' control.

The City Planning Commission, within the next two or three weeks, will take the first step toward drastic and comprehensive amendment of the city's zoning regulations in order to attack the problem of traffic congestion from every possible angle, it was indicated yesterday.

James Coggeshall Jr. of the First Boston Corporation is the choice of the nominating committee of the Bond Club of New York to succeed Lee M. Limbert of Blyth Co., Inc., as club president, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, May 2--In the first three months of this year 11.159 new stock corporations were filed with the Secretary of State, 7,473 more than were chartered in that period last year. In March 3,688 were filed, against 2,438 in 1945.

Theft of a mink jacket and six pieces of jewelry valued at $32,300 from the Waldorf-Astoria suite of Alphonso Valdes, prominent Puerto Rican industrialist and former political figure, was disclosed yesterday by police of the East Fiftyfirst Street station.

CHICAGO, May 2--Representatives of locomotive engineers and trainmen abruptly ended their conference with railroad management today, breaking off negotiations which were begun Monday to avert a country-wide rail strike called by the two unions for May 18. The discussions, lasting nearly four days, appeared to be fruitless.

Aggregate net earnings of 300 of the country's leading corporations were sharply lower in the first three months of this year, compared with those of both the preceding quarter and the comparable period last year, the National City Bank of New York said in its May Bank Letter, published yesterday.

Prince Georges County, Md., announced yesterday that it would open bids on May 14 on 1,100,000 of school bonds dated June l, 1946, and due en each June 1 from 1947 to 1966. Interest must not-exceed 5 per cent.

WESTPORT, Conn., May 2--A Westport fireman and a truck driver lost their lives and eight other persons were injured critically tonight as the result of a truck crash on the Boston Post Road near Sylvan Avenue here. The dead were former Fire Chief Francis P. Dunnigan, 33 years old, of Westport, and John Lowell of Providence R.I.

World Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis, who has begun preparations at Pompton Lakes, N.J., for his title bout next month, and Challenger Billy Conn, training at Greenwood Lake, will visit the offices of the State Athletic Commission at 12:30 today for a physical check-up.

A reduction of $413,000,000 in total loans and investments of the New York City reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System, in the face of a rise of $12,000,000 in the loan total alone, reflected the large redemption of Treasury certificates on May 1, the report for the week ended last Wednesday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated.

The nation's breweries have halted approximately $75,000,000 worth of new construction and remodeling of plants gas a result of Federal restrictions on building and the order cuttins brewers' use of grains 30 per cent, it was learned yesterday.

Eight teams entered the quarter-final round of the national contract bridge team-of-four tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt trophy last night. They were survivors of a field of thirty-eight teams that started play Monday night. The tournament is being held at the Hotel Pierre.

The American Export Lines served notice yesterday that it would fight the Government's avowed intention to rewrite shipping contracts on a retroactive basis and claim taxes on funds on which the lines had received tax exemption.

Net income of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company for the first quarter of this year amounted to $3,744,555 after taxes and all charges, compared with $4,322,929 for the initial three months of 1945, William F. Humphrey, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting held here yesterday.

The State is undertaking a program "to increase legal child labor" as part of a campaign to attract badly needed farm workers to New York agricultural areas this summer, State Labor Commissioner Edward Corsi announced yesterday.

Louis and Ida Galatioto of Providence, R.I., have purchased the property at 1984-86 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, containing six stores and forty-four apartments, from the Chersam Realty Corporation, marking the first change in ownership in fourteen years. "Her Kind of Man," a Warner Brothers melodrama, will open at the Strand this morning. Dane Clark, Janis Paige and Zachary Scott head the film's cast, with Faye Emerson, George Tobias and Howard Smith among the supporting players. Frederick de Cordova directed and Alex Gottlieb produced.
WASHINGTON, May 2--The Czechs and the Poles have got into a new boundary squabble that illustrates why the United States wants to arrange a European peace settlement in Paris as soon as possible.

BOSTON, May 2 (AP)--Miss Zara du Pont of Cambridge, sister of the late Senator Coleman T. du Pont of Delaware, died yesterday at the New England Hospital for Women. Her age was 77.

Reports from various branches of the food field indicate little change in market supplies this week-end. Meats are as hard to come by as ever, according to the New York Council of Wholesale Meat Dealers and the Meat Trade Institute, with lamb the only kind that has shown even a slight improvement.

A strike was called at the Jamaica race track yesterday but the sport went on as usual. The walkout had considerable effect on the program, though, inasmuch as it made for an inordinately large number of scratches, with the result that the fields were comparatively small and the betting total of $1,961,530 proved the smallest amount during the local season.

A branch of New York University, which will accommodate 500 Westchester County high school graduates, who might have been denied a college education because of filled quotas and long waiting lists in universities throughout the East, will open in the White Plains High School this September, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced last night.

BOSTON, May 2 (AP)--Ted Williams, who is fighting off a threatened sinus attack, drove a tenthinning homer into the right field bull pen today to give the Red Sox a 5-4 triumph over the Detroit Tigers. This stretched Boston's winning streak to seven in a row.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., May 2-- Anthracite operators of Pennsylvania sent word late today to John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, that their negotiating committee was prepared to meet him and his committee to discuss new contract terms.

At the annual meeting of the Vulcan Detinning Company yesterday in Jersey City, N.J., stockholders were informed by Alfred C. Buttfield, vice president and general manager, that the net income for the first quarter of this year was less than in the corresponding three months of 1945.

Jacob Luschnitski, a Soviet citizen who stowed away on a ship for New York in March, leaped overboard from an American Victory ship on which he was being deported on Tuesday, but was rescued in the harbor and taken back to Ellis Island under guard of immigration agents, pending further study of his case, it was disclosed yesterday.

NANKING, May 2 (U.P.)--Gen. George C. Marshall, United States Presidential envoy, has asked the Chinese Communists to hand over Changchun, Manchurian capital, to the Chinese Nationalist Government, the Chinese Central News Agency asserted today.

Stockholders of the City Investing Company at a special meeting yesterday approved a split of each outstanding no par common share into six shares of $5 par value. The split will become effective today, Robert W. bowling, president, stated.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)-- --Mobile rehabilitation centers moving from community to community were recommended today as a means of educating and rehabilitating the country's handicapped.
Ralph Bellamy, the actor, made a ten-minute appearance in the Empire State Building yesterday and received checks totaling $3,000.

BUENOS AIRES, May 2--The Argentine regime by a decree tonight assumed authority over the six hitherto autonomous universities of Argentina, naming Federal directors for all of them with orders to follow Federal instructions and "recommend reforms."

WASHINGTON, May 2--Vanishing of prospects for action this session of Congress on an outright merger of the armed forces was privately conceded today by proponents and force was gathering behind efforts for a compromise.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Any further Jewish immigration into Palestine will be resisted with all the forces at the disposal of the 'Arab world, according to a statement issued here today by the head of diplomatic missions repre senting five Arab States.

Who will take the responsibility for carrying out the recommendations of the Anglo-American Committee's report on Palestine? Prime Minister Attlee's statement in the House of Commons is a clear indication that the British will not assume the burden alone.

WASHINGTON, May 2--One week from today the British Ambassador to Washington is going home to stay. The Earl of Halifax is retiring from public life after a career in politics, statesmanship and diplomacy which few of his own nation have excelled...

Arousing themselves from the general lethargy imposed by the drowthy warmth of a perfect spring afternoon, the Yankees exploded with an eight-run barrage in the fourth inning yesterday that sent the invading Indians reeling out of the Stadium crushed and beaten in the finale of their threegame series here before a paying crowd of 21,511.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The Army has set up a new Research and Developments Division, with general staff status, to serve as General Eisenhower's agency for exploration of military-scientific problems, including atomic and electronic wagons of the future.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 2 (AP) --The Rock Hill Farm's Shaffie remained unbeaten in three starts when he galloped to a four-length victory in the eighth Ral Parr Stakes at Pimlico today.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)-- Robert Murphy, director of the newly organized American Baseball Guild, today outlined some of the things which the guild hoped to accomplish, among them establishment of a minimum salary of $7,500 a year for major league players.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 2 --More than 100 Government officials and parent education leaders from all sections of the United States were warned tonight not to let their program slip into the pitfalls "in which ordinary education has so tragically fallen."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 2-- The Rev. Dr. William W. Leete, pastor of Dwight Place Congregational Church until his retirement in 1913 and well-known lecturer, died in his home here yesterday at the age of 91.

A general embargo on railroad freight and a 25 per cent cut in passenger service has been ordered by Washington to conserve coal piles dwindling as the result of the thirty-two-day-old bituminous strike. [1:8.]

TOKYO, Friday, May 3--Japan's first group of top-flight war-criminal suspects, headed by former Premier Hideki Tojo, today for the first time faced the Allied Military Tribunal and heard its president, Sir William Flood Webb of Australia, describe the proceedings begun this morning as unrivaled for their importance in the course of history.

ST. LOUIS, May 2--A four-run outburst in the ninth coupled with nine innings of exceptionally fine pitching by our left-handed Dave Koslo, enabled Mel Ott and his Giants to make a surprisingly dramatic exit from Sportsman's Park today to the consternation of 3,276 onlookers.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated yesterday over a fairly wide range, although the volume of business was rather small Final prices were at virtually the best levels of the day and 10 to 17 points net higher than on Wednesday.

A complaint alleging that Consolidated Edison rates for electricity are oppressive and unreasonable, and asking that the Public Service Commission undertake a broad investigation to determine fair, rates and a fair rate base was filed yesterday with the commission on behalf of thirty-one consumers of current.

Confidential orders, it was learned yesterday, have been sent out to New York City policemen, particularly those where commercial garages are clustered, to keep special watch for hijackers who steal merchandise by the truckload and dump it on the black market.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)-- President Truman declared today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was a vital cog in the Government machine and asked Congress to extend ita life beyond its present expiration date, Jan. 22, 1947.
LONDON, May 2--Quiet marked the early phases of today's trading on the stock markets today, but several sections tended to strengthen and at close the tone was firm.
Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Cutting of 15 East Eighty-eighth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Grace, to Gordon R. McGrath, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Sims McGrath of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Assurances from Representative E.E. Cox of Georgia that the State Department had been purged of "hundreds" of "undesirable" employes and was continuing "the housecleaning from top to bottom" paved the way today for House action on a $10,000,000 appropriation to maintain the department's international information and cultural program.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 2-- All inhabitants and property owners of the Finnish island of Elgoe and two adjoining islands just east of highly strategic Hangoe have received orders to clear out immediately, according to information received in Stockholm diplomatic circles today.

WASHINGTON, May 2--President Truman said today that he would not hesitate to restore food rationing if a disastrous crop failure made it necessary. However, speaking at his news conference, he repeated his belief that rationing here would not meet the international food emergency because there was not time to put such regulaticn into force.

The American Youth Orchestra under Dean Dixon gave the second of a series of three concerts sponsored by the Manhattan-Queens division of the Greater New York Committee of Russian Relief last night at Carnegie Hall. Leonard Bernstein was chairman of the event, the proceeds of which will go toward re-equipping the First Central Medical Institute of Moscow.

About a year ago a report of a Congressional food investigation was issued and created a favorable impression because of its clear-cut analysis and forthright recommendations for changes in policy. The chairman of that committee was Clinton Anderson.

DETROIT, May 2--William B. Stout, aircraft and automobile designer, disclosed today what he called "the car of the future," a craft with a body of fiberglas plastic material with engine in the rear and no chassis or axles.

Gen. A.A. Vandegrift, United States Marine Corps commandant, declared last night that 150,000 boys club members had served in the armed forces of their country. Only 5 per cent of the clubs' membership old enough to fight was rejected for physical deficiencies, he added.

VIENNA, May 2--The news that the Foreign Ministers conference in Paris had decided against the return of South Tyrol to Austria was received with dismay in Vienna and in Austrian Tyrol with evidence of public resentment that included a general strike and street demonstrations.

The last-minute reprieve granted men's clothing manufacturers yesterday by the Office of Price Administration to make up surcharges incurred during the first 1946 quarter under MAP is a makeshift that will permit shipments during the balance of the month, with the major pricing problem still unsolved, according to industry spokesmen.

Six employes of the Port of New York Authority received its distinguished service medal for outstanding service to the port district and the Authority, in ceremonies yesterday in the auditorium of the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

JERUSALEM, May 2--A letter was sent today by the Arab Higher Committee to the British Cabinet, warning that if the recommendations of the Joint Anglo-American Committee of Inquiry on Palestine are adopted, the Arabs will resume "the national struggle."

Dr. Paul Klapper, president of Queens College, was made an honorary member of Sigma Alpha, honorary service society of the College of the City of New York's School of Business and Civic Administration, at Charter Day exercises yesterday morning in the school's auditorium.

From three low wood buldings on the north border of the Bronx, fifteen tons of food and clothing leave daily for Europe. Going by truck and train to city piers, they are "S.O.S'" supplies being sent by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee.

The growing acuteness of the black market in lumber and other building materials has compelled the Office of Price Administration to place price enforcement in this industry in top priority on a nation-wide basis, it was disclosed yesterday.

Women the world over are watching with interest and hope the daily results of the subcommission on the Status of Women. Their wishes for the success of the delegates in improving the status of women are revealed in the many messages and letters received by the subcommission.
NORTH CASTLE, N.Y., May 2--Our current fishing trip did not get off to a very good start, for although we tempted the Kensico trout with every lure at our disposal, the morning brought us no fish.

CHICAGO, May 2--The costliest fire in turf history, a flash blaze which destroyed twenty-three thoroughbreds valued at $500,000, razed the barn housing the Maine Chance Farm horses at Arlington Park early today.

Dr. Simon Flexner, who won world renown by his investigations into infectious diseases, notably dysentery, meningitis, infantile paralysis and lethargic encephalitis, died at 12:05 A.M. yesterday in the Presbyterian. Hospital, of a coronary occlusion following an operation. His age was 83.

Unconfirmed rumors circulated here yesterday that the controversial Palestine issue might be placed before the United Nations Security Council on the ground that the Arab-Jewish conflict for supremacy was a threat to the peace of the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, May 2--President Truman said today that he had given no assurances to Secretary of State James F. Byrnes during their telephone conversation yesterday that the French loan arrangement was "on the way" or that emergency foodstuffs requested by France would be forthcoming soon.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 (AP)--A big five-run second inning, sparked by triples by Hank Camelli and Bob Elliott, gave the Pittsburgh Pirates an 8-to-3 victory over the Phils in the rubber match of a three-game series today. A crowd of 4,061, including 603 women, saw the game.

LANDSBERG, Germany, May 2 (AP)--Officials of the Landsberg Jewish displaced persons camp, where inmates wounded eighteen Germans in a riot Sunday, charged today that junior officers and enlisted men in the United States Military Government were guilty of anti-Semitic behavior.

Maguire, deputy administrator of the Civilian Production Administration, described today as essential the development of programs to channel more fabric into the men's wear industry.

WASHINGTON, May 6--Gustav Metzman, president of the New York Central Railroad Company, spoke today for the Class I railroads of the United States in support of their request for a rise of 25 per cent in freight rates from May 15.

The administration of rent control in the New York district has bogged down so badly that the nine area rent offices between this city and Poughkeepsie and on Long Island were shut yesterday to the public for an entire week.

The city took steps yesterday to conserve fuel in anticipation of the prolongation of the coal miners' strike. Officials met with coal dealers and fuel oil distributors to check up on the available supply in the metropolitan area.

Philip Goodstein, 52 years old, of 781 Seventh Avenue, a former Office of Price Administration attorney, was sentenced by Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate in the War Emergency Court yesterday to ten days in the workhouse for collecting $300 for renting an apartment to a veteran in violation of OPA regulations.

TOKYO, May 6--The first session of the new Japanese Parliament, elected for the first time under Allied rules permitting women and men under twenty-five to cast their votes, will be called into session probably within the next ten days.

State Senator and Mrs. W. Hardy Hill of Hilo, Hawaii, have made known here the engagement of their daughter, Shirley, to Harold Arnold Steiner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Steiner of Deal, N.J.

WASHINGTON, May 6--The Senate entered its expected "week of decision" on the British loan today with the bill under day-long attack by Senator Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, and with prospects dim for adoption of closure.

WASHINGTON, May 6--Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson said today that he still expected that wheat-export goals for May and June, plus the deficit, would be met, but warned that what the coal strike did to train transportation might hamper the sending of grain to famine areas overseas.

WASHINGTON, May 6--President Truman sent to Congress today an estimate of $7,246,335,200 of military appropriations for the War Department for the fiscal year beginning July 1, including $500,000,000 for military government and relief in occupied areas and $200,000,000 for the Atomic Service, formerly known as the Manhattan Project.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Downes, daughter of Mrs. Davenport Downes of 1 West Seventysecond Street and Olin Downes, also of this city, to Richard H. Williams 3d, son of Mrs. Richard H. Williams Jr. and the late Colonel Williams of New York and Morristown, N.J., took place yesterday morning at the home of the bride's mother.

BALTIMORE, May 6 (AP)--They rolled out the welcome mat at Pimlico today for the Kentucky Derby gang heading to town for the rich Preakness Stakes on Saturday. The Foxcatcher Farm's Hampden--fit and ready--was first to check in from the Blue Grass country.

ALBANY, May 6--Horace A. Demarest, Deputy State Motor Vehicle Commissioner and a Republican leader in Queens, was dismissed from his State job today. He was involved in an investigation of the Ku Klux Klan by Attorney General Goldstein.

LONDON, May 6--Revolutionary proposals to provide London with high speed railway travel through a system of deep under-river subways and to provide for the razing or removal of stations, bridges and viaducts were published today.

NANKING, May 6 (AP)--Agreements for a unified constitutional Government of all China must be honored fully, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek told leaders of his regime today in an address calculated to ease the distrust among Chinese factions.

WASHINGTON, May 6--The French voters may not have been aware of it when they voted against the Communist-Socialistbacked Constitution yesterday, but by doing so they helped to solve a problem that has been troubling some United States Government officials for the past few weeks.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, May 6--The Netherland Government was attacked in Parliament today for what was called its too conciliatory attitude toward Indonesian demands. The Dutch Indonesian policy was called unworthy of the Netherlands, fruitless and unconstitutional.

Emphasizing antiques as practical furnishings of special beauty with two rooms arranged by noted interior decorators, the New York Antiques Fair opened yesterday afternoon at the Seventeenth Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 6 (AP)-- Momo Flag, 6-year-old American Flag gelding, making his second start of the season, came from far back to win the $3,500 Warren Purse today at Narragansett Park.
ROME, May 6--Victor Emmanuel is still King of Italy today, and Vatican sources continue to issue strong denials that they have anything to do with the question whether he will abdicate.

The Dessoff Choirs and the chorus of Bennington College joined forces for a concert at Town Hall last night, under the direction of Paul Boepple. George Finckel, 'cellist; Carol Greenfeld, harpsichordist, and string players of the Bennington College Orchestra also took part in the concert.

Testimony and the final pleas of counsel were completed yesterday in the trial of 14-year-old Jack Turk, charged in Queens County Court with the slaying of a 3-yearold girl whose parents had hired him as a "baby sitter."

After dipping into George Freedley's reservoir of theatrical archives at the Public Library's Fifth Avenue branch, local historians concur in reporting that New York hasn't witnessed "Henry IVPart 2" since the James K. Hackett appearance way back in 1867.

MADRID, May 6--Several arrests were made here over the week-end following the distribution of anti-Franco literature. Pamphlets, distributed widely through the suburbs, lampooned the Government and its chief officials.

The Public Service Commission refused yesterday to approve a plan offered by the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and its subsidiary, the Surface Transportation Company, for financing the purchase of 400 buses to replace street cars in Manhattan in the fall.

Rodgers, vice president and general sales manager of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, declared yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 6--The military government's weekly report disclosed today that German border police were to be moved, beginning on May 10, to a distance of one kilometer from the American zone's boundaries "in order to prevent clashes with armed border patrols of the Allied nations."

PARIS, May 6--In a long, detailed memorandum setting forth the monetary value of Italy's contribution to the Allies' war effort, her Government has warned that a decision by the Foreign Ministers' conference to make her pay reparations would negate any reconstruction plan for the country.

A detailed and inferentially critical report summarizing the difficulties encountered by the United Nations in establishing interim headquarters in New York will be presented today at the opening session of the important Headquarters Commission.

Hints of approaching peace in China alternate with reports of spreading warfare. On the one hand, Chiang Kai-shek in Nanking invites renewal of parleys between the opposing factions by a promise that agreements reached by the Political Consultative Council two months ago will be enforced strictly.

MOSCOW, May 6--The UNRRA reports the fats situation particularly grave in the Ukraine, as in most countries where UNRRA supplies are arriving, according to Paul White, deputy chief of the Ukrainian mission, who stopped in Moscow today on his way to the United States.

Loew's, Inc., in its statement of operations covering the twentyeight weeks ended March 14, disclosed yesterday a net profit of $8,952,067 after all charges, including $6,337,900 reserve for Federal taxes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.Y., May 6 --Acceptance of the program advocated by many American industrialists and their "wrecking crew" in Congress would bring about a complete collapse of the national economy, with 25,000,000 to 30,000,000 unemployed, Sidney Hillman declared here today.

Submitting the only bid, a syndicate of bankers headed by Kuhn Loeb Co. won yesterday the award of $60,000,000 of bonds of the Texas New Orleans Railroad Company. The group then sold out the whole issue immediately on public offering.

DETROIT, May 6 (AP)--Passenger automobile and truck production increased slightly last week but prospects of maintaining the upward trend are daily becoming more dubious.

PARIS, May 6--The United States delegation to the conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers now is convinced that it is vital to make the beginning of a discussion of the problem of Germany, especially since the parley has struck a snag on the Italian treaty, it was learned tonight.

Four rules for "good citizenship in a world community" were presented yesterday at the opening of a joint conference of the National Council of Women of Canada and the National Council of Women of the United States in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
A cheering crowd of 14,212 underprivileged youngsters had the time of their young lives yesterday at a special morning matinee of the circus at Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, May 13--As the House of Commons began a threeday grind of dealing with more than 100 amendments to the coal nationalization bill today, evidence accumulated that the mine workers and the Government were growing farther apart on future plans for Britain's sickest and most vital industry.

WASHINGTON, May 13--Proposals designed to improve the efficiency of Congress by modernizing its organization and procedures were presented formally to the Senate today, with the sponsors hopeful of at least getting a start toward this goal before final adjournment.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)-- Attorney General Clark informed a Senate Labor Subcommittee today of an "alarming" increase in teenage crimes since 1939, including a rise of 198 per cent in the arrest of girls under 18.

Ralph Richardson, who is featured in the Old Vic reparatory stage company at the Century Theatre here, has been signed to a five-year film contract by Sir Alexander Korda.

NUREMBERG, Germany, May 13 (AP)--A defense witness testified before the International Military Tribunal today that the German naval command, in the summer of 1941, had "even ordered submarines withdrawn from American waters" lest an incident provoke the United States to war.

Socialized dentistry would ultimately lead to the "toothlessness of persons in the United States," Dr. Harvey J. Burkhart, described by his associates as the "dean of New York dentistry," declared yesterday in a condemnation of legislation to socialize the medical and dental professions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 13-- Enterprise Productions, the Charles Einfeld-David Loew producing company, announced today that Ginger Rogers' agreement with the organization to star in "Maggi July" has been written into a formal contract calling for one picture a year for four years, with the actress sharing in the profits of the ventures.

Zeo Ritter of 200 West Twentieth Street, Manhattan, for many years a resident of Brooklyn and long a principal benefactor of the Israel Zion Hospital, Tenth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, died in that hospital yesterday after a week's illness of heart disease. He was 70 years old.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 13 (AP)-- Prime Minister Ahmad Ghavam said tonight that the delegation from the self-proclaimed autonomous province of Azerbaijan left Teheran this morning, but he added it was possible the negotiations might be reopened later.

DACHAU, Germany, May 13 --An American military court today sentenced fifty-eight operators of the Mauthausen concentration camp to die on the gallows for the torture and murder of thousands of imprisoned victims of German persecution. Three other defendants received life sentences.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 13 (AP)-- Jack McHale pounded his third homer and chased in half of the runs necessary for the Buffalo Bisons to polish off Jersey City, 6 to 5, tonight. It was the fifth triumph for the Bisons in their last seven starts and boosted them over the 500 mark in the standings.

Prompted by the story of an easy escape from the prison ward of the Kings County Hospital in Brookyln, Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court ordered yesterday an investigation of the ward's administration.
Operations of L.C. Smith Corona Typewriters, Inc., and subsidiaries in the first three months of this year produced a net income of $204,560 after all charges, including taxes, of $158,192.

BERLIN, May 13--The increasing rate of depletion of raw materials indispensable for Berlin's industrial activity is forcing the city to the brink of bankruptcy, and a crisis in unemployment is anticipated within the next three weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 13--The United Mine Workers of America, made a specific demand for a levy of 7 per cent on the industry's $1,000,000,000 payroll for a health and welfare fund today, two months after their officials began negotiating with the bituminous operators for a new wage agreement.
Stocky Jimmy Callahan, versatile New York State Maritime Academy star, gave a one-man show as his team vanquished Fordham, 8-6, yesterday at Fort Schuyler in the Bronx.

Dr. Rudolf Kagey, Assistant Professor of Philosophy at New York University and the author of ten mystery stories under the name of Kurt Steel, died early yesterday at the Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. His age was 41.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)-- President Truman signed today a bill authorizing $500,000,000 in Federal expenditures during the next seven years for an airport construction and development program.

Lame and aged visitors to the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be on an equal footing with other art lovers under new plans for the museum, which will make every corner of the "art treasure house" accessible to anyone in a wheelchair, it was learned yesterday.

Prices of large truck tires are being reduced in the Metropolitan area by some independent tire dealers 10 to 20 per cent under Office of Price Administration ceilings, it was learned yesterday. This is the first important break in the price of any type of tires since before the war and, according to dealers, resulted from the large oversupply of those sized tires.

The United Aircraft Corporation voted yesterday a semi-annual distribution of 50 cents a share on the common stock, onehalf the rate paid in 1945, and reported a net loss of $505,921 for the first quarter of 1946 after various adjustments and credits, comparing with net income of $3,547,781 in the first quarter of 1945.
John A. Coleman was re-elected chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange for a fourth term yesterday.

Behind locked doors and under FBI surveillance to prevent sharp horse-trading, the War Assets Administration put 249 ex-service horses on sale to thirty-nine exservice men yesterday at $100 a head in the Squadron A Cavalry Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Park Avenue.
The national railroad strike, called for 4 P.M. Saturday, will hit New York City harder than the coal, steel and tug strikes combined, a survey among city and trade executives indicated yesterday.

Dr. Stephen Duggan is a pioneer in opening up world highways for cultural exchange. Now, at 75, he is resigning as head of the Institute of International Education, which he founded. He feels that traffic will be so heavy over these roads in post-war years that a younger man should direct it.

PITTSBURGH, May 13--Officials of the United Mine Workers in western Pennsylvania opened a campaign to get their men back into the mines of this district tonight after only 20,000 answered John L. Lewis' call for a truce in their strike.

Ralph E. Taggart, president of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, announced at the annual meeting of stockholders at Philadelphia yesterday that the company expected to carry on a vast coal stripping project for at least ten years near Shenandoah, Pa., commencing this summer.

JERUSALEM, May 13--The largest single group of Jewish illegal immigrants yet encountered, numbering 1,800, has been intercepted aboard a 2,000-ton Rumanian vessel heading for Palestine from Rumania, a British naval patrol told Haifa authorities today.
NANKING, May 13--Gen. Ho. Ying-chin announced here today that he would retire in a few weeks as Chief of the Chinese General Staff, a post he has held for eight years.

All of the traditional delights of the carousel--the color, the gaiety and even the rhythm--have been captured by Mary Stonehill, mural designer, in an exhibit that opened yesterday at the Architectural League Building, 115 East Fortieth Street.

PARIS, May 13--In one of those ambiguous statements at which French officials are adept, Andre Le Troquer, Minister of the Interior, denied tonight that he had threatened to dismiss the Prefect of the Vendee Department if he attended former President de Gaulle's meeting there yesterday.
After holding within a narrow range all day yesterday, the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 9 points lower to 1 point higher than Saturday's final levels.

WASHINGTON, May 13--The forthcoming financial aid of the United States will constitute a "psychological liberation" of France, Leon Blum, French Ambassador-at-Large, told overseas writers here today in announcing the successful outcome of his mission.

A memorial chair was dedicated in the name of Florence Nightingale, founder of modern nursing, in a ceremony yesterday at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. Eight hundred persons witnessed the unveiling of the chair on the day following the 126th anniversary of the birth of Miss Nightingale.

SIMLA, India, May 13--With the break-up of the round-table political discussions the British Cabinet mission is now drafting its recommendations relating to the early establishment of an interim popular government and to a modus operandi whereby India might proceed to independence.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 13-- Kirtlang King, State manager of The United Press, addressing forty members of New York State Society of Newspaper Editors at the opening of their two-day spring conference here today, urged improvement of the Legislature's system of the recording of its proceedings.

CLEVELAND, May 13 (AP)--No effort has been made in the last ten days to head off a strike by Brotherhoods of Railroad Trainmen and the Locomotive Engineers set for next Saturday, a spokesman for the trainmen said today.

Renewed assertions that the Franco Government in Spain is a permanent threat to international peace and security because it is a "fascist regime geared for war and bent on aggression" were offered yesterday by the Spanish Government-in-Exile.

PARIS, May 13--Secretary of State James F. Byrnes told the Council of Foreign Ministers today that American authorities in Germany had been instructed to propose that the Allied Control Council form a special four-power committee to investigate the present state of German disarmament in all four occupation zones.

BERLIN, May 13--Under orders of the Coordinating Council of the Allied military government of Germany, all German military and Nazi memorials will be destroyed by Jan. 1 and all books glorifying nazism or militarism will be confiscated. It is assumed the books will be burned.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)-- The House and Senate finally approved today the spending of $400,000,000 to subsidize increased production of building materials as horse builders reported that many structures would be left half-built unless the Government acted at once.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 13--A strong statement of policy against any effort of the Communist or Socialist parties to infiltrate into the leadership of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, will be one of the principal orders of business at the organization's third biennial convention which opens here tomorrow, it was reported tonight.

TRIPOLI, Libya, May 13--The leading Libyan politicians had all but agreed on the form of government and the chief of state when the abandonment of Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin's plan for a united and independent Libya offered at the Paris Conference of Foreign Ministers struck them like a thunderclap.

LONDON, May 13 (AP)--Freddie Mills, British Empire light heavyweight champion, was forced to skip rope today in order to keep his weight below the 175-pound maximum for tomorrow night's world title fight with Gus Lesnevich of Cliffside, N.J.

TOKYO, May 13--The new Parliament elected in Japan's "first democratic general election" probably will be debarred from consideration of the vital issues now facing the empire for about another month because of the tangled political situation. Thus far, this has prevented the formation of a new Government.

HARRISBURG, May 13--Thousands of Pennsylvania's striking soft-coal miners who refused to return to the pits today will be eligible to collect unemploymentcompensation benefits beginning next Monday, William H. Chesnut, Secretary of Labor and Industry, said today.

Herman T. Stickman, State Commissioner of Housing, announced yesterday that the State would seize eighty apartments in two apartment hotels at Long Beach, L.I., this morning, to provide quarters for victims of a fire at the Broadway Apartments on March 12.

TOKYO, May 13--Within six weeks the Japanese reparations picture will be clarified so that industrialists will be able to plan for the future with confidence, Edwin W. Pauley, President Truman's separations representative, declared today in an interview.

A national accident-reduction campaign sponsored by the International Association of Chiefs of Police will get under way here tomorrow with a two-week police traffic safety check among motorists who violate traffic regulations.
A full report covering policy, program and composition of a permanent United Nations Committee on the Status of Women was adopted unanimously yesterday by the subcommission dealing with that subject.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 14--High level British orders have been received here calling for the withdrawal of all British troops from Cairo and Alexandria before the end of July.

Henry Goelet, operator, has purchased the eleven-story loft building at 736 Broadway for cash above a first mortgage of $65,000. The building, on a plot 25 by 115 feet, contains a store and ten lofts. Arthur Eckstein, Inc., and Simon Osherow were the brokers.

A syndicate formed by David Rapoport has purchased the blockfront taxpayer property at 68-98 East Burnside Avenue, the Bronx, through Carstens Linnekin, Inc. The property is assessed at $480,000 and was sold at a reported price of $450,000.

TOKYO, Wednesday, May 15 (AP) Abruptly breaking off defense arguments, the International War Crimes Tribunal today ordered an indefinite adjournment while it considered a motion by five defendants for a bill of particulars.

Eventual reunion of Christendom was predicted yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning, in what was expected to be his last official address at a convention of the New York Episcopal Diocese. He spoke at the 163d annual session of the diocese at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and the Synod House adjoining it at 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Andrew G. Clauson Jr., Richmond representative on the Board of Education, was unanimously elected president of the public school system's governing body by his six fellow-members at the board's annual meeting yesterday at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn. He succeeds Miss Mary E. Dillon, president of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company, whose second term as head of the board expired last week.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 14 (AP)-- Jafar Pishevari, Premier of the self-proclaimed autonomous regime in Azerbaijan Province, declared tonight that troops of the Central Iranian Government had "moved to our borders, but we are not afraid of an attack."

BOSTON, May 14 (AP)--Behind the four-hit pitching of Lefty Jimmy Wallace, the Braves tonight scored their fourth consecutive victory, defeating the Pirates, 5--1, before 20,762 spectators. It was the second night game in Boston's major-league history.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 14 (AP) --The national match game champion, Joe Wilman of Chicago, won the all-events title and Leo Rollick of Santa Monica, Calif., took the singles crown as the forty-third annual American Bowling Congress' championship tournament ended a sixty-two day stand tonight.

William Helis, New Orleans sportsman, had his disappointments in the Kentucky Derby and Preakness, but he had plenty to beam about at Belmont Park yes-. terday, when his smart filly Earshot took the sixteenth Acorn Stakes and was only a fifth of a second off the record for this $10,000-added gallop.

MONTREAL, May 14 (AP)--Morris W. Wilson, president and managing director of the Royal Bank of Canada and chancellor of McGill University, died in a hospital here last night after a brief illness. His age was 63.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 14--A stockholders' committee headed by Morton F.Stern of Jules Bache Co. of New York won control of the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company at the stockholders' annual meeting here today.

New developments in metals and plastics will permit manufacture of decorative lighting fixtures at lower prices within a year or so, Kathleen L. Hanway, home lighting consultant for Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., predicted last night.
Municipal elections in eleven New Jersey communities were marked yesterday by the return to office of most of the incumbents seeking re-election.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 14--The United Steel Workers of America, CIO, acting on a proposal by President Philip Murray, adopted today unanimously and without a word of debate a statement of policy against efforts by "any outsiders," Communists, Socialists or any other group "to infiltrate, dictate or meddle" in the union's affairs.

Leonard Steiner of Brooklyn Tech, the second ranking favorite, advanced to the quarter-final round of the Eastern interscholastic tennis championship for high schools yesterday on the Sunrise Courts, Sunnyside, Queens.

The off-shore fishing is getting better every day, despite the opposition of the weather man, and a number of the party boats are coming in with excellent catches of mackerel, with an occasional pollack.

Downtown traffic with its quirks and snarls was a mere incident yesterday to Lieut. Herbert Kleinfield of 430 East Eightysixth Street, a disabled veteran, who passed a driver's test for the second time. Seated in a Ford sedan with special equipment, he guided the car from Henry Street to the Motor Vehicle Bureau at 155 Worth Street and grinned when congratulated at the finish.

AKRON, Ohio, May 14--Deploring a lack of unity within his own union, Samuel Wolchok of New York, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes of America, CIO, opened today the first convention of the organization since 1942.

Plans for a fifteen-story and penthouse store and office building to be erected at 333-339 Eighth Avenue and 302-306 West Twentyseventh Street at an estimated cost of $1,100,000 were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Joseph J. Furman, architect, for the owner, Gramercy Estates, Inc., of 60 Wall Street. Work on the structure will be started when priorities are available.

J. Carlton Ward Jr., president of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, in the annual report issued yesterday, advised stockholders that sales in 1945 totaled $41,831,481, compared with $93,212,963 the year before.

AKRON, Ohio, May 14--The nation's rubber industry should be able to meet the demand for passenger automobile tires by the early part of 1947, while the call for truck tires should be satisfied by the third quarter of this year, executives of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed quiet yesterday 5 to 18 points net lower than on Monday. Prices reflected near-month liquidation and some Southern selling. The market started unchanged to 5 points down and continued to decline.

WASHINGTON, May 14--A 1946-47 wheat program issued today by Secretary of Agriculture Clinton Anderson called for continued food-conservation measures throughout the coming year.
ST, LOUIS, May 14--With a rush of home runs, the Yankees launched their first invasion of the West today at Sportsman's Park where, before a gathering of 5,399, they downed the Browns, 6 to 2.
RYE, N.Y., May 14--New York State should and probably will be first in aviation activities, members of the New York State Aviation Council were told today in the Westchester Country Club here.

The Anaconda Copper Mining Company and Subsidiaries announced yesterday in a preliminary report for the March quarter a consolidated net income of $534,626, equal to 6 cents each on 8,674,332 shares of capital stock outstanding. The company's share of estimated combined net loss of subsidiaries unconsolidated and not included in consolidated income account, was $5,401.

A thousand New York retail butcher shops, chiefly in Brooklyn, locked their doors yesterday for the duration of an all-out war on the black market in meat, and their owners joined indignantly in an organized drive to cripple illegal operations by shutting down every retail meat outlet in the city.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The State Department announced today that the United States had renewed its official request that American aviators who had been aided by Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch during the war be permitted to testify in his behalf during his trial ...

WASHINTGTON, May 14--A new deadlock in the bituminous coal wage negotiations is expected tomorrow when the operators will reject the United Mine Workers' demand for a 7 per cent payroll levy for a health and welfare fund.

LONG BEACH, L.I., May 14-- State officials set up an office in the Community Hall here this afternoon to interview the victims of the Broadway Apartments fire of last March and others eligible for housing in two State-seized apartment hotels and a third building whose owners volunteered quarters for distressed families.

Charges of black market traffic in railroad and sleeping car reservations will come up for an airing at a meeting of the Eastern Railroads Presidents' conference tomorrow afternoon at the Biltmore Hotel, it was learned yesterday.

Bread and cake were served for dinner last night in most city homes and restaurants, but not because Mayor O'Dwyer's proclamation Monday establishing three wheatless meals a week was not meeting a cooperative response.

WASHINGTON, May 14--A Government loan of $400,000,000, spread over five years, will be necessary to get the Philippine Republic started on its fiscal way, President-elect Manuel Roxas told an informal gathering of members of Congress today.

Great art belongs to all the people. So, although the individual who started to walk out the door with one of its treasures under his arm would be quickly stopped, the Metropolitan Museum, open freely to all to enjoy, is in large measure the property and the responsibility of every one of us.

Georgia O'Keefe's show opened with a preview last evening at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. Installed in galleries on the third floor, this survey of a distinguished American artist's work to date will remain on view until late next August.

WASHINGTON, May 14--Army Air Forces surgeons, acting mainly "for the sake of morale," have conducted extensive experiments in exposing guinea pigs to radar waves, and have reported that the waves seem entirely harmless.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Charges of obstructing a vital function of government were made against two major wire news services of the United States today by Ralph McGill, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, and Mark Ethridge, editor of The Louisville Courier-Journal and Times.

PARIS, May 14--Secretary of State James F. Byrnes, clearly recognizing that the Council of Foreign Ministers had drifted into new diplomatic doldrums, made a desperate effort this afternoon to revitalize the mechanism for making the peace treaties.

WITH typical British adherence to tradition, Bruce Woodcock suddenly became very horizontal in the fifth round of his bout with Tami Mauriello at Madison Square Garden the other night. PHILADELPHIA, May 18--Getting the jump at the start as Navy missed its cue in heading under way, Pennsylvania defeated the varsity crews of Annapolis and Princeton today over the Henley Course of a mile and five-sixteenths on the Schuylkill.

POMPTON LAKES, N. J., May 19 (AP)--With a capacity crowd of 500 looking on, Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis flashed some of his best form in going four rounds against his sparring partners today in preparation for his title bout with Billy Conn, June 19.
LONDON, May 19--The feature of the financial markets here last week was the somewhat astonishingly sharp fall of gilt-edge securities after the announcement of terms of the new Government loan.

Lawler to prevent it from releasing to newspapers resolutions it may adopt on matters of general interest until they have been approved by higher authorities of the Legion.

New furnishings for children's rooms combine post-war materials and designing with gay decorative motifs.

The bodies of three women and a man, passengers and driver of a taxicab that plunged into an East River Basin after crashing through, the barrier of a dead end street, presumably early yesterday morning, were taken from the water last night off Fifth Street, Long Island City, Queens.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 18 (Delayed)--President Romulo Betancourt declared today that there was no "strike atmosphere" around the discussions between oil companies and workers and that Communist influence was insignificant.

PARIS, May 19--Rising partisan passions occasioned by the gathering momentum of the campaign, preparatory to the national election on June 2 indicated today that the party truce signed in January was being abandoned by common consent.

CHICAGO, May 19--With the Government taking an estimated 60 per cent of the Federally inspected output of lard, supplies of that commodity available for domestic distribution are running well below requirements, and a shortage in vegetable oils used for shortening and margarine is having a tendency to tighten the situation further.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 19 (AP)-- Booth Tarkington, novelist and playwright, died in his home here tonight after an illness of two months. His age was 76.

MEXICO CITY, May 19--Babe Ruth saw another baseball game here today which impressed him so little that he had to ask his wife later what the score had been. But directly from Delta Park, where he was again the guest of Jorge Pasquel, he went to his first bull-fight and later reported that a matador had dedicated a bull to him. The Bambino did not forget that by a long-shot.

Making the most of a bad bargain which brought them together at a time when both sides were grousing over losing streaks, the Giants and Pirates did just about the best that circumstances would permit as they split a doubleheader at the Polo Grounds yesterday before a gathering of 40,713 fans.

WASHINGTON, May 19--Social Security in the United States should offer comprehensive benefits to all who need them, a study conducted by the Brookings Institution has concluded.

LONDON, May 19--With the arrival today of Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King of Canada and Norman Robertson, his UnderSecretary for External Affairs, the Dominions conference will be resumed tomorrow for a last week of discussions that will include empire trade. Questions of strategy and peace, however, will still dominate the talks.

In a cash deal, the five-story business building at 34 West Thirty-fourth Street has been sold by Frederick Brown to the Nehama Realty Corporation for investment. Qunito Herbst, brokers, represented the buyer of the building, the store, basement, second and third floors of which are leased to Foot-Saver Shoes until Jan. 31, 1949.

Summer A. Parker, architect and engineer, who built The Cloisters at Brooklandville, Md., a Baltimore suburb, and furnished it with many French gothic objects of art, died Friday in his Baltimore residence, 913 St. Paul Street, at the age of 64, according to word received here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 19--National production of steel ingots suffered another drastic cut last week when the rate dropped 10 points to 48 per cent of rated capacity. A greater reduction is expected to take place this week, leaving the industry in its worst position since the complete shutdown in January.

TUNIS, Tunisia, May 18 (Delayed)--Although it has been officially dissolved and barred from freedom of assembly, the Tunisian nationalist movement still exists under cover. Its political directorate meets secretly. It claims to have cells all over the country.

George Farkas, well-known in the pre-war capitals of Europe as an industrial and interior designer, and now located in Miami Beach, Fla., will open a divisional office and showroom at 24 University Place here late this month, it was announced over the week-end.

Before 900 persons, including a group of small neighborhood youngsters who bore red-lettered posters almost as tall as themselves that spelled "Welcome Cardinal Spellman," the Archbishop of New York yesterday afternoon parted a silk white ribbon at the entrance to the Casita Maria Settlement House at 61-63 East 107th Street.

The Belgian soft surface floor coverings industry, now operating at 60 per cent of capacity, is aiming at restoration of annual American export volume to the pre-war level of $8,000,000 by the end of 1947, Louis de Poortere, president of the Belgian Federation of Manufacturers of Floor Coverings and Upholstery Fabrics, said last week.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., May 19--The calm before the storm settled over hotels here today as the Daughters of the American Revolution assembled for their fiftyfifth Continental Congress, which officially opens tomorrow. The delegates took part in a historic tree ceremony and a memorial service for the 2,000 members who died in the past two years.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 19--The Tabriz radio announced tonight that Iranian armed forces had attacked Azerbaijan. The attack was made from the southwest in the Kurdish areas around Lake Urmia, the radio added.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP)-- The St. Louis Cardinals trotted out a pair of their prize southpaws before a Philadelphia National League record crowd of 34,049 today and annexed two games, 9--5 and 4--0. The double victory returned St. Louis to first place in the league standings.

Dr. Joseph W. Barker, president of the Research Corporation, 405 Lexington Avenue, announced yesterday grants amounting to $175,000 to twenty-eight universities and colleges for a year's research in physics and chemistry. He said $2,500,000 would be granted to educational institutions in the next five years.

An investor bought from the Lejack Holding Corporation the seven-story elevator apartment house at 1950 Washington Avenue, corner of 178th Street, in the Bronx, through City Wide Brokerage. The new owner took the property subject to a mortgage of $96,500.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (U.P.)-- Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, said today that John L. Lewis, head of the UMW, was within his legal rights in calling the soft coal strike and demanded "a complete overhauling of our labor laws" to protect the public from "hardships and privations."

Confusion over the five-day postponement of the railroad strike order brought a sharp increase yesterday not only in passenger service on ferries and on buses but also in vehicular traffic using the tunnels and bridges between New York and New Jersey.

CLEVELAND, May 19--The Yankees did some fancy slugging today at the huge municipal stadium to celebrate their first appearance of 1946 on the shores of Lake Erie with a twin-edged victory over the Indians before 55,310 fans, the season's record here.

Toys made by members of the Junior Red Cross in New York City schools are being used not only as playthings, but even as decorations in the ship's nursery on the war-bride transport Thomas H. Barry, Dr. Charles S. Johnson, director of the youth organization here, announced yesterday.

The approach of the United States Naval Academy to the warfare of the future, as outlined in a recent dispatch to this newspaper, should bring a sepulchral grin to the visage of John Paul Jones, beneath the Academy's chapel. He gave the Navy one of its great quotations, "Sir, I have just begun to fight!" He said it when his own ship, the Bon Homme Richard, was about to sink--and he won a great victory.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 19 (AP)-- It takes no poll of the fans to name the popular favorite to win the 500-mile race at the Indianapolis motor speedway May 30.

WASHINGTON, May 19--John W. Snyder, Reconversion Director, reported to President Truman tonight that 2,080,000 persons, including 970,000 veterans, will want to go to college next fall, but that only 1,000,000, including 690,000 veterans, can be accommodated.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 19-- By the margin of one boat's position in the series of three races for the Sparkman Trophy, Corny Shields won the season's opening of the international class.

For the first time in its history New York City knows how many young children are in its day-care centers and what is happening to them there. In all, 18,325 children under 6 years of age attend 415 centers. 50 per cent of which are commercially operated, according to a report announced today by the Acting Commissioner of Health, Dr. Israel Weinstein.

BUFFALO, May 18--A succession of "colossal events" which "add up to nothing less than social revolution in the broadest and truest meaning of that term" was called tonight "the order of the day" by Kenneth L. M. Pray, dean of the Pennsylvania School of Social Work.

MARGRATEN, the Netherlands, May 19--On the outskirts of this small community are the graves of some 20,000 Americans who died in the Germans' 1944 Ardennes offensive, the crossing of the Roer and Rhine Rivers and later in the final triumphal sweep over Germany.

During the past week manufacturers were engaged in collecting fall lines for openings expected to start the first week in June in the wholesale markets, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

NEW DELHI, India, May 19 (Reuter)--With the Congress party's final answer to the British Cabinet mission's proposals for India's future still undecided, Mohandas K. Gandhi tonight reported to the party's Working Committee on his two-hour talk earlier today with British Secretary of State for India Lord Pethick-Lawrence and Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade.

ROME, May 19--The new "modus vivendi" for Italy evolved by the Big Four contains secret annexes whose existence is not indicated in published summaries and which are likely to cause startled indignation in both America and Italy if they become known, according to highly reliable information received privately from Paris.

LONDON, May 19--Lieut. Gen. Wadyslaw Anders' Polish Army of about 110,000 men in Italy, source of much of the recent friction between the British and Polish Governments, will be demobilized in Britain shortly but the soldiers will be maintained in camps in Scotland until work and homes are found for them.

WASHINGTON, May 19--Federal officials hope that resumption of wage negotiations between the railroads and brotherhoods of engineers and trainmen by Tuesday, or possibly tomorrow, may pave the way for amicable adjustment of the dispute and consequent cancellation of the country-wide strike planned by the two unions, it was reported today.

LONDON, May 19 (U.P.)--British newspapers warned today that diversion of an additional 200,000 tons of wheat to near-famine areas would mean black bread, drastic reduction of cookies, cakes and cereals and severe penalties for waste.

The city's library situation is "critical," according to a report made public yesterday by the City Planning Commission, which recommended setting up regional branches, new branches and subbranches and extensive improvements to libraries already existing.

WASHINGTON, May 19--Improved discipline and morale in the Army and definite progress in organization, tactics and technique were evident in the course of a 4,000-mile trip just completed yesterday to five key Army posts and schools in this country.

JERUSALEM, May 19 (U.P.)--The British High Commissioner for Palestine, Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan C. Cunningham, invited Arab and Jewish leaders today to meet tomorrow. It was believed that he would propose a round-table conference in London on the Palestine inquiry report.

The appeal for gifts for the hungry and starving millions overseas is being met by the American people with more than traditional generosity, Secretary of Commerce Henry A. Wallace, national chairman of the Emergency Food Collection drive, announced last night.

The order to abandon ship was issued twice early yesterday in the fog off the New Jersey coast as four vessels were involved in two collisions within seven hours. No lives were lost and the ships, a tanker and three freighters, moved toward port here.

PATERSON, N. J., May 19 (AP) --John Swier of Astoria, N. Y., capped a banner day of midget auto race triumphs at Hinchliffe Stadium today by taking the feature event, reduced from five miles to four because of an accident involving Dee Toran of Paterson.

Governor Dewey, Mayor O'Dwyer and Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, are scheduled to speak at a dinner beginning the campaign of the Community Committee of New York in behalf of the United Jewish Appeal tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 19--A conference of eighteen nations and several international organizations, advanced many months by the increasing urgency of the world food situation, goes into emergency sessions tomorrow to devise a "positive, definite, concrete program" for meeting immediate critical famine problems, and to develop long-range plans for the abatement of hunger in the world.

A "million dollar" central headquarters for more than 100 unions in the Greater New York Industrial Council, CIO, to provide offices for locals and also recreation rooms, will be established here as soon as the building shortage is eased, it became known yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, May 19--The first week of share transactions proved an anticlimax for the Amsterdam Bourse. Expectations of lively trade were disappointed, firstly as the result of the initial huge gaps between bid and offer prices and secondly by the pronounced lack of buying activity either for speculation or investment.
More than 150,000 New Yorkers celebrated the first peacetime "I Am an American" Day in five years in Central Park yesterday.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 19-- There's a new sensation in dog shows--the toy dog that keeps on winning. Today the Pomeranian Little Timstopper took best in show at the forty-fourth annual event of the Long Island Kennel Club.

DETROIT, May 19 (AP)--The Tigers broke out their home-run power in the second game of a double-header today, beating Boston, 3 to 1, with three circuit smashes after the league-leading Red Sox had taken the opener, 4 to 0, on a 10-hit attack behind Dave (Boo) Ferriss' seven-hit hurling.
The question whether Russian troops have been withdrawn from Iran will come before the United Nations Security Council when it reconvenes at Hunter College at 11 A.M. Wednesday.

TOYKO, Monday, May 20 (UP)-- Demonstrations including "physical violence which undisciplined elements are beginning to practice" will not be allowed to continue, Gen. Douglas MacArthur said in a formal statement today.

The life insurance companies of the United States are conducting an intensive, world-wide search for thousands of policyholders and their beneficiaries who are unaware that millions of dollars in paid-up insurance and dividends have accumulated on policies issued to them from three to fifty years ago.

MANILA, May 19--The initial public disclosure of a secret government behind the so-called Hukbalahap organization, which has been conducting a small scale civil war against the Philippine Army's military police, has been made by the American-owned newspaper, The Manila Daily Bulletin.

For the second time this season and within the space of five days the Dodgers have been swabbed with a whitewash brush. Ed Heusser of the Reds smeared them yesterday on seven hits for a 4-0 triumph. Howie Pollet of the Cardinals first turned the trick last Wednesday.

FORT WORTH, Tex., May 19 (AP)--Golf's stretch-running bantam, Ben Hogan, closed with a dramatic five-under-par 65 to smash the course record, capture $3,000 first money and break Harry Todd's heart in the Colonial National invitation golf tournament today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 19-- President Truman received a pleasant surprise on his arrival at Grandview Airport late today when he left his special plane, after a trip from Washington, to find his mother, who he had supposed ill in bed with a cold, on hand to greet him.

In what amounted to a counterforay on the All-America Conference, the Boston Yanks of the National Football League yesterday signed Angelo Bertelli, former Notre Dame backfield ace, to a four-year contract. It had been announced previously that Bertelli had signed with the Los Angeles Dons of the All-America circuit.

Victor Warren Mitchell, well known as a hotel man in Northern and Southern resorts, died yesterday morning of a heart attack in his suite at the Hotel Roosevelt, where he had been staying for a month. At his death he was manager of the Loon Lake House, Loon Lake, N.Y. His age was 50.

MOSCOW, May 22 (AP)--A Pravda dispatch charged today that seven United States bombers piloted by Americans fighting on the side of the Chinese National Army were shot down in Manchuria while bombing Chinese Communist troops.

DeKoning, Long Island field representative of the A.F. of L., demanded that all operating personnel of the big racing plant that straddles the Queens and Nassau County line join the A.F. of L.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- Joseph E. Murphy, retired assistant chief of the Secret Service, died in Goldsboro, N.C., last night at the age of 68, the Treasury was advised today.

Women in all parts of the world are seeking a larger measure of freedom and will have a highly important contribution toward building "a more reasonable and more comfortable world," Pearl S. Buck declared yesterday in Town Hall.
