PARIS, May 22--Fines totaling approximately 1,000,000,000 francs have been levied against blackmarket operators in the past twelve months, according to a report made today by Albert Gazier, Under-Secretary in charge of the national economy.

Jack I. Straws, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., announced yesterday, following a board meeting, that directors had declared an extra year-end dividend of $1 a share for the fiscal year ending on Aug. 3 next, in addition to the usual quarterly dividend of 40

WASHINGTON, May 22--The railroads and eighteen of the twenty railroad unions accepted tonight a compromise proposed by President Truman for a wage increase of 18 cents an hour, but the heads of the trainmen and engineers, who have threatened a strike for 4 P.M. tomorrow, standard Time, viewed the proposal unfavorably.

Eighteen women and one man who each served at least 4,160 hours in local hospitals during the six years from May 4, 1940, received special awards yesterday in Town Hall from the United Hospital Fund of New York.

A further drop of 1,108,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was recorded last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the week, total supplies on hand were 97,050,000, barrels, against 98,158,000 a week earlier and 88,533,000 on May 19, 1945.

DETROIT, May 22--Goaded to fury by a road trip only moderately successful, the Yankees today dealt a savage thrust to the Tigers to defeat them, 5 to 3, in the New Yorkers' first appearance at refurbished Briggs Stadium.

The United Nations Security Council voted yesterday to keep the Soviet-Iranian controversy on its agenda for an indefinite period. Russia boycotted the meeting and will be displeased with the decision.

Sweeping revisions of the city's capital budget for 1946 and its capital outlay program for the three following years, as recommended in the report submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer on April 15 by Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, were tentatively approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

LONDON, May 22--Demobilization as quickly as possible of all Polish forces in Britain, Germany and Italy--perhaps 200,000 in all-- and formation of a Resettlement Corps under British command and law for those who do not want to return home were announced in the House of Commons today by Foreign Secretary.

Foremen are the key to increased industrial productivity and the shop observance of labor contracts, Marvin A. Heidt, vice president of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, said yesterday. He spoke at an industrial relations seminar of the Radio Manufacturers Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The United States is riding toward the crest of a strike wave which probably will not recede until it reaches a peak of 1,000 threatened strikes a month.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- Lieut. Gen. Edmund B. Gregory, head of the War Assets Corporation, said today that "the Republican National Committee has been trying to embarass the administration" on the issue of surplus property disposal.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 22--Eight thousand spectators, including widows of the men slaughtered at Lidice, watched without pity today as Karl Hermann Frank was hanged in Pankrac Prison courtyard for having been chiefly responsible for the massacre.

Mr. and Mrs. James M. Symington of Short Hills, N.J., and Cooperstown, N.Y., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Lispenard Stewart, to Lieut. (j.g.) William Ellery Sedgwick James, Medical Corps, USNR, son of Mrs. Ellery Sedg-...

BOSTON, May 22--The 1945 surplus of the Ford Motor Company increased $12,264,280, equal to $3.55 a share on outstanding capital stock, it was disclosed today by the company's annual balance sheet filed with Henry F. Long, Massachusetts tax commissioner. This compares with $4.61 a share in 1944.

As his contribution to National Maritime Day, Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, demanded yesterday a Congressional investigation into charges that American ship operators had "fleeced" the public Treasury of $21,000,000,000 during the war.

LONDON, May 22--Atomic energy, which has so radically changed British Empire strategy, was the subject of a general report by W.L. Mackenzie King, Prime Minister of Canada, and an exchange of views at the Dominions Conference this afternoon.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 22 (U.P.)--An official of the United States State Department said today that the United States would hold all 372 vessels seized on the Danube River yesterday and would not release them until the "Great Powers" had agreed to free navigation of the Danube.

DACHAU, Germany, May 22 (AP) --Two Americans, including an ambulance driver who had rescued wounded Germans in Normandy, declared today that German troops had clubbed some survivors among captured Americans in the Malmedy massacre and had shot others to death.

WASHINGTON, May 22--A civil affairs agreement is being concluded with Italy covering the presence of American troops in the country after the revised armistice terms take effect, it was learned today.

LENINGRAD, Russia, May 22-- The city of Leningrad is slowly recovering from its ordeal by fire and famine, bomb and shell which won it the title of one of four "hero" cities of the Soviet Union. But that ordeal left the spacious capital of the Czars and its people exhausted and unkempt.
CHICAGO, May 22--To complement the miracle of American production, sales executives today were called upon to transform mass production into wealth by mass consumption, through mass distribution.

Thousands of Americans in ports throughout the country celebrated the nation's first post-war Maritime Day yesterday, paying tribute to valiant ships and valiant men of the merchant marine for their major roles in victory.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22--An aggregate of $71,250,000 of bonds, 342,500 shares of preferred stock and 359,733 shares of common stock were registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by five companies.

NUREMBERG, Germany, May 22 (U.P.)--A German naval attache in Tokyo informed Berlin on Dec. 3, 1941, of the impending attack on Pearl Harbor, documents submitted to the International Military Tribunal today showed.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The welfare fund, crux of the dispute which led to seizure of the coal mines, is a widely established institution and some labor leaders consider John L. Lewis as a late starter in a field in which their unions pay out many millions of employers' dollars yearly for benefits.

TOKYO, May 22--Shigeru Yoshida was officially appointed by Emperor Hirohito this morning to serve as the new Premier of Japan at the head of his newly selected conservative Cabinet. In his first public statement today he pledged immediate action to solve the nation's critical food problem and appealed for united support.

WASHINGTON, May 22--A proposal for a new emergency agency to deal with world food shortages developed today in a special committee of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization and seems likely to go before the full meeting of the conference Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22--Setting an eleven-year record, $599,217,000 of new equity securities were effectively registered for cash sale during the first quarter of 1946, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today in its statistical bulletin for April.

PARIS, May 22--Only today was Secretary of State James F. Byrnes' speech of Monday extensively commented upon in official circles here, where it was regarded as proposing merely a new procedure instead of a concrete plan for solving the European--and above all the German--problem.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The Senate Banking Committee recommended today a continuation of price subsidies until May 1, 1947, limited to $1,100,000,000, or about half the amount the administration had originally requested but fifty per cent above the total the House had granted on the primary item of food.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Postmaster General Hannegan, who is chairman of the Democratic National Committee, assured a committee of protesting House Democrats today that the National Committee would not take sides in local primaries, but he made it plain that he would continue to welcome the support of the Political Action Committee of the CIO.

PLANDOME, L.I., May 22-- Under ideal weather conditions, of which Mrs. R.M. Torgerson took full advantage, the Cherry Valley player won her second one-day golf tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association by carding a 42, 38--80 for low gross honors over the hilly Plandome Golf Club course today.
The Long Island State Park Commission announced yesterday that the bathing season at Jones Beach would begin officially Saturday.

The Central Park Zoo was agog with rumors and opinions yesterday. Most of the inhabitants sent congratulatory messages to Mr. and Mrs. Camelus Bactrianus, while others adopted a truculent attitude. The stork was both condemned and praised.

New York housewives, in cooperating tonight with the Mayor's request for a Thursday wheatless dinner, can profit by the ingenuity of the Society of Restaurateurs and use a muffin recipe, developed by that organization for its 240 members in the city, which calls for no flour but relies instead on mashed potatoes.

Myrick Ebben Land, Laura Hoyle Davis and Barbara Nell Neblett, students graduating this June from the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism, have been named winners of the 1946 Pulitzer Traveling Scholarships, Carl W. Ackerman, Dean of the Journalism School, announced last night.

Although the average American waterfowl shooter draws a large circle around the date he bags his limit of ten ducks (possibly less next fall) the European waterfowler considers it a dull day if two men are able to carry his gamebag.

NANKING, May 22--Government forces have captured the Communist stronghold of Kungchuling, it was announced today, and were reported to have pushed to within twenty miles of the Communist-held Manchurian capital of Changchun.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Surplus property disposal has always worried the President. Long ago he foresaw the possibilities of corruption in the sale of the vast Government stores left over from the war. He is determined that no such deals shall blemish his administration.
An unprecedented invasion of New York was staged yesterday by 6,671 Navy and Marine veterans of Pacific service who arrived from Guam on the Navy transport Wakefield.

Msgr. Francis J. O'Hara, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Angels, Fourth Avenue and Seventy-third Street, Brooklyn, died early yesterday morning of a heart ailment, at the age of 77. His death ends a pastorate of more than twenty years. He had been a priest more than fifty years.

Talk that a third world war is inevitable was decried last night by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., United States representative to the United Nation Security Council, in an address at the annual dinner of the National Institute of Social Sciences at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

IN that masterpiece of selective candor, "The Summing Up," Somerset Maugham spoke of having written at the outset of his career a novel of the Renaissance based on an idea from Machiavelli. Now, half a century, or so later, at the height of his celebrity, he has written another novel of the Renaissance based on an idea from Machiavelli.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., May 22 (AP)--Rear Admiral Andrew Theodore Long, USN, retired, died here yesterday, at the age of 80.

Settlement of 21,500 canceled war contracts exeeding $1,100,000,000 in sales value has been almost completed by the Bendix Aviation Corporation, Ernest R. Breech, the president, reported yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick was praised as "one of the outstanding religious leaders of all time" by John D. Rockefeller Jr. at a meeting last night in the nave of Riverside Church, at which the congregation jointly honored Dr. Fosdick and his wife.

Patrick A. Connolly, retired United States Army officer who served in the Spanish-American War and the first World War, and later was a member of the engineering department of the Board of Transportation, died on Tuesday at his home, 4154 Bronxwood Avenue, the Bronx, after a brief illness. Bela Raphael Simons, 3 -yearold orphan who found a father among the thousands of American GI's in Germany, arrived here in an American Overseas Airlines plane yesterday to begin life anew in the free world she has never known.

PARIS, May 22--The struggle between the Communists and conservative bankers for control of the Societe Generale, one of the recently nationalized deposit banks, came out into the open for the first time today.

The Eastman Kodak Company made public yesterday its findings on long-range radioactivity effects of atomic bomb explosions. The findings, together with those of other observers, indicate that temporarily radioactive by-products of a single bomb spread in the course of a few days over an area about the size of Australia.

If the current rate of fire losses continues unchecked, the damage this year will exceed $600,000,000 and make 1946 more costly than the years of the great San Francisco and Chicago fires, Frank A. Christensen, president of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, declared yesterday.
CHICAGO, May 22 (U.P.)--Robert R. Wason, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, praised John L. Lewis today as a labor leader, saying he was honest and loyal to America.

The Harlem Savings Bank sold the two-story taxpayer at 40-48 West Burnside Avenue, southeast corner of Grand Avenue, the Bronx, to the Troler Realty Corporation for a cash consideration of $42,500 above a purchase-money mortgage of $150,000. Returning service men, worried about women taking their places in business while they were away, may forget their anxiety on this score, Joseph B. O'Connor, regional director of the United States Employment Service, said yesterday.

The campaign by shutdown retail butchers to track down priceceiling violations among fellowmerchants moved forward yesterday with reports that 150 new complaints were added to the 300 turned over on Tuesday to a trade committee for investigation and submission to law enforcement agencies.

The trotters and pacers will be back at Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L.I., tonight, there to remain until the fall. The 140-acre farm estate of William B. van Leer on the Hillsdale Road in Atlantic Township, N.J., adjoining the Big Brook Pheasant Farm, was purchased by Leroy A. French, through Paul R. Stryker, broker. The property includes two dwellings.

All Spanish citizens who so desire may now bear arms in anticipation of an attack on Spain by the Soviet Union, Dr. Jose Giral y Pereira, Premier of the Spanish Republican Government in exile, declared yesterday.

Members of America's first overseas tennis argosy since 1939 began to gather in New York yesterday with the arrival of John Kramer of Montebello, Calif.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23--Four companies filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission registration statements covering $52,000,000 of debentures, 400,000 shares of preferred stock and 425,507 shares of common stock.

Tens of thousands of commuters jammed every available bus out of Manhattan's several midtown terminals yesterday from as early as 2 P.M. until several hours past the normal homebound rush in the evening. Long lines extended from terminals into the bus yards.

The six buildings and railroad property covering the block at Third Avenue, Harlem River, Mott Haven Canal and East 134th Street, the Bronx, have been sold by the Edroyal Corporation to the Genhar Realty Corporation for...
A countrywide railroad strike, which if prolonged may cripple the national economy and affect the life of every citizen, went into effect, at 4 P.M., Standard Time, yesterday.

Although train trouble was added to the track's private strike problem, racing carried on pretty much according to schedule at Belmont Park yesterday, with 23,370 undiscouraged customers turning out under a beaming sun for the daily scrimmage with the mutuels.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Miss Margaret Truman's graduation from George Washington Univer sity next week will be the signal for the largest family gathering of Trumans and Wallaces thus far in the White House, according to plans announced today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 23-- When Communists attempted to hold a meeting here this afternoon in defiance of police orders mounted police charged on the crowd and dispersed it. Special cavalry and mechanized units were standing by this evening, with machine guns trained on the public square of Largo Carioca.

Fists flew for the second successive day at Ebbets Field yesterday as Dixie Walker of the Dodgers and Len Merullo of the Cubs, among others, traded blows in a pre-game flare-up witnessed by only a scant quorum of the ladies' day gathering of 22,078 that later saw the home players gain another overtime decision over their feuding rivals from Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP)-- Led by Ralph Kiner's two home runs and double, the Pirates drubbed the Phillies, 10 to 2, today and immediately boarded two buses for home, where they are scheduled to play the Chicago Cubs tomorrow night.

An eighteen-point program for Police Department operations during the railroad strike was made public last night by Mayor O'Dwyer after Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander had ordered twelvehour shifts for all department personnel.
HAVANA, May 23--Walter S. Ward, long-time American resident of Havana, died yesterday in the Anglo-American Hospital, after a long illness.

A quarterly dividend of 40 cents and an extra of 10 cents on the new common stock, both payable on June 29, have been declared by Abbott Laboratories. The quarterly payment is equal to 80 cents on the old common stock, which was split recently two for one and which paid quarterly dividends of 40 cents plus extras.

Michael Todd, producer of Broadway plays, has purchased for investment the two-story business building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 215-19 East Fifty-eighth Street near Third Avenue, from Frederick Brown, who acquired it some time ago, from the estate of John M. Dodd. The Quis Agency, Inc., was the broker in the resale.

New York City has enough food in storage and is assured of sufficient replenishments of perishables by truck every day to have no cause for worry over its food supply as a result of the rail strike, Markets Commissioner Eugene G. Schulz said last night.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Not since President Truman shook hands with the street throngs through the White House fence on V-J Day has the executive establishment been the scene of such unusual goings-on as those which accompanied the continuous Cab- ...

PITTSBURGH, May 23--The soft coal situation turned for the worse today as an estimated 108,000 miners in Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Ohio remained at home on the second day of Federal operation of the mines, an increase of about 15,000 over yesterday.

Simple lines, beautiful workmanship and neutral colors were outstanding characteristics of a collection of hats by Mme. Germaine Legroux, presented yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. The showing vvas marked by a return of the sports hat.
A sixth baby among the scores who arrived in New York aboard two Army war bride ships from Europe early this week died yesterday in a Pittsburgh hospital.

CHICAGO, May 23 (AP)--The country-wide railroad dispute, involving an estimated 1,250,000 of more workers, started in July when the five operating brotherhoods and fifteen non-operating unions served demands on the carriers.
The City Planning Commission voted in executive session yesterday to ask the Board of Estimate for a $100,000 appropriation for a survey on traffic conditions in the city.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)-- A House Judiciary Committee subcommittee was urged today to approve a bill exempting mutual news-gathering organizations from provisions of the Sherman AntiTrust Act.

A gala tribute was paid to the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York last night when the annual Red, White and Blue Ball was given in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton in recognition of the organization's twenty-seven years' uninterrupted service as a club for enlisted personnel of the armed forces.

ROME, May 23--The Roman Catholic Church in China was raised from missionary status and a Catholic hierarchy was set up there by a decree dated April 11, it was revealed today by the Vatican. Thomas Cardinal Tien, the first Chinese Cardinal, is accordingly made the first Archbishop of Peking.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Miss Nandine Szechenyi, youngest daughter of Countess Laszlo Szechenyi, the former Miss Gladys Vanderbilt, and the late Count Szechenyi, one-time Minister of Hungary to the United States, was married here this morning to Alexander E. Eltz of New York, son ...

After an initial shutdown that halted all rail movement in and out of New York, some Eastern railroads attempted last night to resume operations on a limited basis with volunteer crews. There was little immediate indication, however, that the attempts would be sufficiently, successful to permit anything approaching normal pas- ...

NEWARK, N.J., May 23--William K. Jackson, newly elected president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, and Gov. Walter E. Edge called tonight for positive action to end the wave of strikes that they said are bringing the nation's economy to a halt and to prevent a recurrence.

The National Association of Transportation Advertising, Inc., has completed media studies of car card advertising in six cities in cooperation with the Advertising Research Foundation of the American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of National Advertisers, it was announced yesterday by Philip J. Everest, managing director, at a press conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, May 23-- The Aluminum Company of America will build a $30,000,000 rolling mill capable of producing more than 10,000,000 pounds of sheet and plate a month, it was announced here today by Thomas D. Jolly, Alcoa vice president and chief engineer.

The stock market approached yesterday the zero hour in the railroad crisis with mixed reactions. Until the final hour of trading the list gave evidence of adherence to the belief that a "break" in the conference at the White House might avert a tie-up of the nation's rail transportation.
PALM BEACH, Fla., May 23--Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, widow of the Philadelphia financier, died here today of a coronary thrombosis at the age of 81.

Prohibitions on exports by the Civilian Production Administration seriously retard operations of American foreign traders and threaten the national economy, it was asserted yesterday at a meeting of the International Trade Section, New York Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Whatever conclusions the Security Council of the U.N. may reach about the case of Iran, and whether or not it decides to state and somehow act on these conclusions, many officials and diplomats here have arrived with certainty at three.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 23 (U.P.)-- Central Government troops with full equipment are moving northward daily from Teheran to reinforce frontier garrisons, and informed circles asserted today that an Iranian "fifth column" was being nurtured within Azerbaijan.

Trailing the Cards by four runs, the Giants loaded the bases with none out in the ninth yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Johnny Beazley, supreme throughout the afternoon, was in as tight a spot as any pitcher with a 4-0 advantage might be.

The commercial airlines of the nation, to which Government officials are looking for the handling of high priority cargoes of food, mail and emergency supplies during the rail strike, put into effect last night a stringent cargo priority system. The Railway Express Agency was named as handling agency for all air shipments.

DACHAU, Germany, May 23 (AP) --Elite Guard Pvt. Gustav A. Sprenger said in a statement today that he had shot two Americans who helped a wounded German and that German troops had used captured Americans for target practice in the Battle of the Bulge.

The principal Eastern representatives of the two striking railway brotherhoods remained glued to their rooms last night at the Times Square Hotel, awaiting any instructions from their chiefs in Washington which might contain the magic word formulas calling off the strike.

SEOUL, Korea, May 23--Col. M. Preston Goodfellow, political adviser to Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, commander of United States forces in Korea, will leave here tomorrow morning for Tokyo and the United States. He has been here five months trying to unify southern Korea's warring political factions.
WASHINGTON, May 23--The Congressional Pearl Harbor investigating committee formally closed its record today, six months and eight days after beginning the inquiry.

UP to a couple of years ago the only way either Lee Oma or Jersey Joe Walcott could get into Madison Square Garden on a fight night was to pay his way in just like any other common cash customer. But tonight those same two operatives will make off with a major portion of an expected $100,000 gate. Fish or poultry again will provide the backbone of week-end meals for most of us, since the United States Department of Agriculture, the Meat Trade Institute and the New York Council of Wholesale Meat Dealers present another dismal picture of meat supplies.

Jumping off to a six-run lead in the first inning, City College concluded its 1946 baseball campaign by routing Brooklyn College, 11--3, in a Metropolitan Intercollegiate Conference contest yesterday on the Kingsmen's diamond.

A quartet of Russian singers put on a lively program of music of the land of their birth at Town Hall last night. This program was further proof that the musical scene has changed in recent years. In the past the season has drooped or been moribund at this time of the year.

BUENOS AIRES, May 23--The elimination of all political parties that supported his election was dictated tonight by Juan Domingo Peron. The President-elect told the Argentine public over the radio that all would be incorporated into one "National Revolutionary party."

A couple of tenements and a string of run-down two-story workshops surrounding a debris-packed courtyard on East Forty-ninth Street between Second and Third Avenues have been extensively remodeled by James Amster, New York decorator, into an elaborate community to be known as Amster Yard.

New Yorkers, young and old, will be able to visit such famous ships as the Midway, Missouri and Franklin D. Roosevelt when the Eighth Fleet drops anchor here on Monday for Fleet Week. Small craft will ferry passengers to and from the giant ships.

When the average man registers his preference for a Cape Cod colonial house in home building surveys, he is not referring to that style in the technical sense, but rather to the hominess and coziness which it symbolizes, Charles E. Whitney, publisher of Interiors, told members of the Architectural League last night. Mr. Whitney spoke at a dinner held at league headquarters, 115 East Fortieth ...

Eleven hundred persons, including nine descendants of Booker T. Washington, attended ceremonies in the Gould Memorial Library of New York University, University Heights, yesterday, to watch the unveiling of a bronze bust of the Negro educator by his granddaughter, Gloria Davidson Washington.
G. Crawford Eadie, formerly a vice president of Webb Knapp, Inc., announces the opening of offices at 52 Vanderbilt Avenue where he will conduct a general real estate business.

Argentina has placed an embargo on all hide exports, it was learned yesterday. The action, according to importing interests in this country, was precipitated by the international hide and leather agreement, which sets purchase price ceilings lower than Argentina producers are being offered by most European nations.

DETROIT, May 23--The magic hammer of Thor could have produced no greater damage than the magic bats of the Yankees in Briggs Stadium today as they loosed their noisiest bombardment of the campaign, pounded five of Steve O'Neill's hurlers into pulp, rolled within striking distance of a couple of records and overwhelmed the Tigers by 12--6.

The War Shipping Administration liner Washington, held up in the port because seamen did not like one of the pursers and demanded his removal, was withdrawn from service yesterday and 800 passengers expecting to sail were notified that the ship was no longer on the active list.

LONDON, May 23--Dissatisfaction here with the attitude of Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, has reached a point where it now seems fairly certain that the British Labor Government will not let him prevent its determined efforts to force independence upon India.

LONDON, May 23--Philip Dragoumis, Greek Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, declared today that British troops would remain in Greece "so long as other troops remain in neighboring countries." He made clear that he was referring to Red Army troops in Bulgaria and Rumania.

The vanguard of Admiral Marc A. Mitscher's powerful Eighth Fleet, New York-bound after five weeks of intensive training maneuvers in the Caribbean, is due to arrive off Ambrose lightship at noon today and proceed to moorings in the Hudson River reaching as far north as Spuyten Duyvil, the Third Naval District announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 23 --Asserting that the individualized system of medical care now practiced in the United States had given this country the best health record of any nation on earth, Dr. William B. Rawls, chairman of the coordinating council of the medical societies of New York City, warned today that "reformers ...

Another Mexican bombshell hit organized baseball yesterday. This time the immediate effect was felt by the Cardinals, who may, or may not, lose the services of three "name" players, Max Lamer, Fred Martin and Lou Klein.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)-- The railroad strike and Government priorities slapped on the use of airplanes tonight threatened seriously to cramp the traveling style of bid league baseball teams.

Sharp disagreement over the proper interpretation of freedom of information developed yesterday between the United Nations Department of Public Information and the Security Council's subcommittee on the Franco regime in Spain, which banned direct radio broadcast of its public proceedings.
LONDON, May 23--Sotch whisky production is virtually at a standstill it was learned today as a result of governmental withdrawal of the industry's barley quota, because of world food shortages.

Mr. and Mrs. Horace Perry, the couple that drove two of the four men charged with the murder of Albert Davidoff, Brownsville prizefighter known as Al (Bummy) Davis, to Kansas City, Mo., from Brooklyn, testified yesterday in Kings County Court that they had done so under threat of bodily harm.

Otto S. Beyer, an adviser on labor relations for the Bonneville Power Administration, warned yesterday against a conflict between the methods employed by labor unions in private industry and those that have been developed in public service under the merit system of civil service.

LONDON, May 23--A hitch has developed in the Anglo-Egyptian treaty revision talks and was the subject of earnest discussion at the Foreign Office here tonight. The biggest debate yet held on the subject of Egypt is scheduled to take place in the House of Commons tomorrow morning.

WASHINGTON, May 23--J.A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior and Federal Coal Mines Administrator, offered to the United Mine Workers today a Government contract which is to remain in force so long as the country's coal properties are in Federal possession.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., May 23 (AP)--Beaten in seven tries this year, Mrs. E. Hineman's Mae Case finally found a field she could handle in the feature of today's program. With Jockey Martin Bletzacker, recently reinstated, in the saddle, the daughter of Case Ace stuck it out long enough to defeat Gustave Ring's Pharaday by a neck.

If the Daughters of the American Revolution did not lay claim to an uncommon devotion to the nation's traditions and if they did not call their edifice in Washington Constitution Hall, they would face much less criticism for their reluctance to permit concerts by Negro musicians in the said hall.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23-- With a few exceptions trains scheduled to leave terminal points in this area today at 4 P.M. or later remain idle on the tracks as their engineers and trainmen joined the strike.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, May 22 (Delayed)--An American library for Germans in the United States zone of occupation stocked with American newspapers, magazines and 3,000 books was opened here today by Brig. Gen. Robert A. McClure, director of the Information Control Division.

Local, suburban and long-distance telephone calls increased considerably in the early afternoon and dropped to less than normal when it became evident that the raliroad strike would not be called off.
BUFFALO, May 23 (AP)--Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board, declared today that he could see no reason for doctors to object to the President's health program.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23--The American Gas and Electric Company of New York City applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to redeem 204,000 shares of its 4 per cent, cumulative preferred stock at the redemption price of $110 per share, plus accrued dividends.

Fires since V-J Day causing the heaviest toll of property and lives in the nation's history were traced chiefly to "war weariness" by spokesmen for the National Board of Fire Underwriters yesterday at the board's eightieth anniversary meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, May 23--The stock markets here were quiet today and losses predominated in irregular price movements. Gilt-edge stocks remained dull and showed fresh declines, although there was a tendency toward recovery before the market closed.

The cotton market was nervous yesterday, with traders awaiting news from Washington relative to the railroad strike. Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved over a range of 13 to 14 points, closing at reactions from the best and at 1 point net lower to 5 points higher than on Wednesday.

LONDON, May 23--The Dominions' Conference ended this evening with all concerned agreed that the bonds of the empire are stronger than ever. ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 23 --The storm raging over the "white artists only" clause that has been simmering for several years finally broke with such fury today at the closing session of the fifty-fifth Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution that the 4,000 delegates were thrown into an uproar four times within fifteen minutes.

Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Commerce, told the delegates at the annual convention of the Brooklyn Jewish Community Council last night that the field of human relations presented to all nations and all peoples the greatest challenge in the world today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 23-- Mrs. Mary Fairchild Low, artist, of 11 McKinley Street, this place, died today. She was the widow of Will H. Low, mural painter, and the first wife of the late Frederick MacMonnies, the sculptor.

Carl L. Norden, Inc., precision equipment designer, has purchased the two-story building at 121 Westmoreland Avenue, White Plains, N.Y., from Westland Associates, headed by Irving Brodsky, attorney. The property, assessed at $79,800, contains 21,000 square feet of floor space.

WASHINGTON, May 23--The sale of the surplus steel plant at Geneva, Utah, the Government's largest plant for the production of wartime steel, to the United States Steel Corporation for $47,500,000, was approved today by the War Assets Administration.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)--A new American weapon described by a Representative as "far more deadly than the atomic bomb" played a brief and guarded part in House debate on naval appropriations today, then was snatched back behind secrecy curtains faster than it came out.
WASHINGTON, May 23--President Truman appealed to the Senate today for prompt renewal of price-control legislation for another year without amendments "that would jeopardize economic stability."

The Engineers Public Service Company yesterday advised stockholders that it is proceeding with its plan of dissolution, in compliance with the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Reporting member banks here stepped up their investments sharply in the week ended Wednesday as an inflow from other centers to this market was offset only partly by Treasury withdrawals, the weekly accounting to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday showed.

New York City Housing Authority yesterday sold temporary loan notes aggregating $3,496,000 and due Dec. 17 to a banking group headed by Chemical Bank Trust Company at a bid of 0.57 per cent.

CLEVELAND, May 23--Not a word and not a hint of optimism came from the national headquarters of the two striking unions, the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, as the paralysis of the strike spread over the land.
CHICAGO, May 23--The strike of locomotive engineers and trainmen halted rail transportation promptly on schedule here today.

Through two income tax returns the Government sought to show to a jury in Federal court yesterday that the resolution of Henry Lustig to be honest with the Treasury Department was a gradual rather than an abrupt decision.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, May 23-- A Chinese Government communique announced today the recapture of Changchun, Manchurian capital. Defending Communist forces withdrew eastward after putting up only weak and scattered resistance within the city.

After a year's ownership, the six-story building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 353-55 West Fortyeighth Street has been resold by Jerome Greene, operator, to an investor for cash over a mortgage of $34,000. Julius Nolte and A.H. Levy were the brokers in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $70,000 and is occupied by the Electronic Corporation of America.

ALBANY, May 23--The Executive Board of Review appointed by Governor Dewey Dec. 29 to analyze the work of the State Division of Veterans' Affairs reported to the Governor today that the State has established "an outstanding system for assistance to its veterans and their families."

MOSCOW, May 23--Earl Browder, former leader of the Communist party in the United States, said in an interview in his suite in the Moscow Hotel today that his visit to the Soviet Union had no relation to his difficulties with the Communist party in America.
About 80 to 85 per cent of the 350,000 to 400,000 commuters who come into New York City daily got home before the railroad strike was called last night.
The railroad strike found the hotels here better prepared than they were last Saturday, when the threatened walkout was called off a few minutes before the 5 o'clock deadline.

In its annual report the Community Service Society has revealed a rise in the number of New Yorkers who sought its help last year with such problems as family unhappiness, broken homes and delinquency. The agency served 27,258 families in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.
MADRID, May 23--At least three of the highest-ranking Republicans have been placed under arrest within the last forty-eight hours, it was learned here today.

The marriage of Miss Marion Therese Butler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Bryant Butler of Riverdale, to Edward Gordon Hooker, son of Mrs. Dimitri S. de Mohrenachildt of New York and of Roland Mather Hooker of Miami Beach, Fla., took place yesterday morning in the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, May 23--The Office of Price Administration suspended from price control today additional electrical machinery and equipment items that had not been included in the wide machinery and decontrol action of April 8.

Provisions to accommodate a heavy increase in automobile traffic into the city, expected as a result of the railway strike, were announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority, the Automobile Club of New York and owners of garages and parking lots.

An additional investment of $65,000,000,000 of private capital may be required to create the facilities needed to sustain nearly 11,000,000 jobs more than in the immediate pre-war era, in the opinion of Prof. Charles C. Abbott, in a report prepared for the Committee for Economic Development.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Total assets of commercial and savings banks amounted to $178,351,000,000 throughout the United States and possessions at the end of last year, the Controller of the Currency has announced. The figure, covering 14,598 banks, surpassed the previous year's total by $25,404,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Sir John Boyd Orr, Director General of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, today proposed the formation of a permanent international food council equipped with the executive authority to put into effect such actions as the FAO might recommend for a world food program.

In the first statement to come out of the Soviet Union in regard to the withdrawal of Russian troops from Iran, the Moscow radio announced last night that the full evacuation of the Red Army had been completed on May 9.

Though a war with weapons has ceased, nursing is still "a patriotic duty," declared Lincoln Cromwell, president of St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Hospital, Morningside Heights, at graduating exercises at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, yesterday afternoon.

Columbia University expects to have about 28,000 students, the largest winter session attendance in the history of the university, when the 1946-47 academic year opens next September, Frank H. Bowles, Director of Admissions at the university, estimated yesterday.

A strike which is nothing less than a national catastrophe began at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon when the railway engineers and trainmen left their posts. At that hour President Truman was making a futile last effort to achieve a settlement by offering the unions more than his own emergency fact-finding board had awarded them.

WASHINGTON, May 23--The Soviet Government has expressed renewed interest, through a note received by the State Department, in beginning negotiations for a credit of $1,000,000,000 from the United States, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, May 23--Air, highway and motor transportation, as well as remaining rail operations, were placed on an emergency basis immediately by the Office of Defense Transportation and the Interstate Commerce Commission as the railroad strike began this afternoon.

CLEVELAND, May 23 (AP)--The Indians squared their two-game series with the Red Sox today, halting the American League leaders, 3 to 2, in ten innings as the clubs went into extra frames for the second straight day.

DETROIT, May 23--Employes of the Ford Motor Company have lost more than $237,000,000 in wages through enforced stoppages since Sept. 1 and the company an additional $500,000,000 by reason of lost sales possibilities.

TOKYO, May 23--The spring growing season has been unusually wet and although small grains have grown well, the next few weeks are considered crucial. Showers have been interfering with the harvesting of wheat. Kyushu and American officials are watching the weather reports nervously.

John Giani, 12 years old, was home at 183 Sullivan Street with a stomach ache recently when word arrived from the Children's Aid Society's Morosini Boys' Club at 209 Sullivan Street that he had won the George Lane Nichols Good Sportsmanship Award.
BALTIMORE, May 23 (AP)-- Arthur James, former New York columnist and editor, and a member of the editorial staff of The Baltimore News-Post for the last three years, died yesterday at the age of 68.

The Congressional inquiry into the events leading up to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor has ended as it began, on a note of Republican suspicion.

WASHINGTON, May 24--Organization of a worldwide "intelligence service" on needs, supplies and production of food was assured today as a committee of the emergency meeting of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization completed its report for submission to the full conference on Monday.

IF ever the world knew a pleasant interval it must have been those relatively tranquil years between 1880 and 1910. There were wars then, of course, but they were waged in faroff parts against benighted natives for their own good. There were strikes and depressions and even minor revolutions, but such distressing disturbances could be ignored without too conscious effort.
